Don't chase success! Do this instead... So much is written and spoken about regarding success in business (and life, for that matter). Yet, I speak to owners and entrepreneurs daily who are not where they want to be, and it's causing stress in the form of poor sleep, strained relationships, and debilitating fear. IMHO, here is what's needed if you're experiencing the above: â¡ Reflect and reassess: Take a step back to objectively evaluate your current situation, goals, and the gaps between where you are and where you want to be. Identify the root causes of any struggles or setbacks. â¡ Redefine your vision: Clearly articulate your desired future state, both personally and professionally. Ensure your goals align with your core values and purpose. â¡ Develop a plan: Outline specific, actionable steps to bridge the gaps identified in step 1 and move towards your redefined vision. Prioritize tasks, set realistic timelines, and allocate resources accordingly. â¡ Implement and adjust: Put your plan into action, but remain flexible. Consistently evaluate progress, celebrate small wins, and adapt your approach as needed based on results and changing circumstances. The key is to approach this process with honesty, self-awareness, and a commitment to continuous improvement. Sustainable success often requires periodic pauses for recalibration and course correction. I'm happy to elaborate further on any part of this suggested approach. ğŸ‘‰ What do I do? ğŸ‘‡ I help B2B consultants, coaches, and startup agencies change how they do business, reach their ideal prospects, and create lifelong clients. Packing dopamine, does this mean anything to you? Your brain is designed to identify what is different, this is not a minor issue. We are talking about survival, we are talking about one winning and the other not. Our brains naturally crave novelty, which can enhance memory and learning. Studies on animals indicate that encountering something new triggers higher dopamine levels, prompting exploration for potential rewards. When we use neuroimaging to observe brain activity, we notice significant responses to novel experiences. Learning something new prompts the formation of new connections and strengthens or weakens existing neural pathways. â†’ Why some brands win and others lose. Teenagers are impulsively consuming information with their cell phones, the dopamine rush what the day is not worth paying attention to. Do you want your next packaging to be difficult to forget, impossible to omit, do you want it to create attention in users who fall in love with it? There are incredible economic differences between a hit and an average product. successful ventures only bet on hits; their business always revolves around hundreds of thousands or million units. â†’ Does your brand dare? Many times we don't dare, we believe that our brand has a heritage, has some values, has something different from the others and that they can and we can't. Well, maybe that's the case, but you if you really want to create an iconic brand, you will need an iconic product, so you'll have a chance to achieve it, if you believe that following the standard, wrapped in intellectualism or quality for example, will be a winning option, perhaps you should analyze it in more detail. â†’ Objective, make them turn their head as they pass by. You think that you need to create an iconic product, a product that at first glance is different from the rest. I have clients who have this very clear and sell millions of units thanks to this very simple thought. Do not come with excuses and tell me all about a complex intricate and intellectual differentiation. That won't make anyone turn their head as they pass by. Ending. As managers, we have the tools to generate a hit, which often involves investment, breaking some taboos, and putting in a lot of work. The result could be a brand or a product that sparks market dopamine, sells by itself, and becomes a magnet for users. Are we ready to accept the challenge and step up to play? You could lose access to your email account forever. Imagine this: your entire company â€“ from sales and marketing to HR and IT â€“ suddenly locked out of their email accounts. All because someone decided to shoot thousands of cold emails/day using tools like Salesloft and Outreach. Sounds nightmarish, but it's a reality for many companies who haven't invested in a proper cold email infrastructure. It's still way too common for us to hear prospects explaining how their entire sales team is blasting emails from their main domain, completely unaware of the risks they're taking. It doesn't matter if you're a small startup or a large enterprise with thousands of employees. If you don't have dedicated domains and infrastructure for your cold email campaigns, you're essentially sitting on a ticking bomb. Your entire company's email deliverability can be compromised, making it almost impossible for any of your emails to land in the primary inbox. This affects not only your sales and marketing efforts but also critical communications across all departments. It's time to take cold email infrastructure seriously. By investing in a separate domain and a proper setup, you can protect your company's email reputation and ensure that your campaigns are actually delivered. â€¦see more

Don't chase success! Do this instead... So much is written and spoken about regarding success in business (and life, for that matter). Yet, I speak to owners and entrepreneurs daily who are not where they want to be, and it's causing stress in the form of poor sleep, strained relationships, and debilitating fear. IMHO, here is what's needed if you're experiencing the above: â¡ Reflect and reassess: Take a step back to objectively evaluate your current situation, goals, and the gaps between where you are and where you want to be. Identify the root causes of any struggles or setbacks. â¡ Redefine your vision: Clearly articulate your desired future state, both personally and professionally. Ensure your goals align with your core values and purpose. â¡ Develop a plan: Outline specific, actionable steps to bridge the gaps identified in step 1 and move towards your redefined vision. Prioritize tasks, set realistic timelines, and allocate resources accordingly. â¡ Implement and adjust: Put your plan into action, but remain flexible. Consistently evaluate progress, celebrate small wins, and adapt your approach as needed based on results and changing circumstances. The key is to approach this process with honesty, self-awareness, and a commitment to continuous improvement. Sustainable success often requires periodic pauses for recalibration and course correction. I'm happy to elaborate further on any part of this suggested approach. ğŸ‘‰ What do I do? ğŸ‘‡ I help B2B consultants, coaches, and startup agencies change how they do business, reach their ideal prospects, and create lifelong clients. You could lose access to your email account forever. Imagine this: your entire company â€“ from sales and marketing to HR and IT â€“ suddenly locked out of their email accounts. All because someone decided to shoot thousands of cold emails/day using tools like Salesloft and Outreach. Sounds nightmarish, but it's a reality for many companies who haven't invested in a proper cold email infrastructure. It's still way too common for us to hear prospects explaining how their entire sales team is blasting emails from their main domain, completely unaware of the risks they're taking. It doesn't matter if you're a small startup or a large enterprise with thousands of employees. If you don't have dedicated domains and infrastructure for your cold email campaigns, you're essentially sitting on a ticking bomb. Your entire company's email deliverability can be compromised, making it almost impossible for any of your emails to land in the primary inbox. Is Speed to Lead still relevant? I've seen a few posts lately saying that it isn't. â€“ 50% of leads will work with the company that contacts them 1st. â€“ Responding to leads within the first min increases conversions by 391%. â€“ Contacting leads within the 1st hour are 7X more likely to become qualified than responding in 2 hours. The challenge with this metric is that it doesnâ€™t account for quality. After all, today, it's all about efficiency. Quality over quantity. The reality is not all leads are created equal, and not all touches from reps are equal. Instead of going for a mere lead response to satisfy your speed to lead SLAs, it's time to actively engage leads. This means focusing on quality of leads and quality of outreach. ğŸ“ˆ Research by MarketingSherpa shows that companies prioritizing lead quality over quantity see a 10-20% increase in sales productivity. ğŸ“ˆ A study by McKinsey shows that tailored communications, which are crucial for engagement, can increase the likelihood of a sale by 40%. So, what can do you? ğğ®ğšğ¥ğ¢ğŸğ² ğ‹ğğšğğ¬ ğ“ğ¡ğ¨ğ«ğ¨ğ®ğ ğ¡ğ¥ğ²: Evolve your lead scoring models. Consider firmographic, demographic, behavioral data and engagement data. Reps must be able to connect the dots. "Hey, we both cheer for the 49ers" isn't connecting the dots. ğ…ğ¨ğœğ®ğ¬ ğ¨ğ§ ğ­ğ¡ğ ğğ®ğ²ğ¢ğ§ğ  ğ„ğ±ğ©ğğ«ğ¢ğğ§ğœğ: Add a calendar link to demo forms so they can schedule meetings directly with reps on their terms. Give a demo on the first call. ğ”ğ¬ğ ğ“ğğœğ¡ + ğ€ğ®ğ­ğ¨ğ¦ğšğ­ğ¢ğ¨ğ§ ğˆğ§ğ­ğğ¥ğ¥ğ¢ğ ğğ§ğ­ğ¥ğ²: Humans are good at relationships, empathy, etc. And bad at other things. ğŸ“¢ Our mission: design and manufacture advanced conductors to modernize transmission & distribution lines âš¡ Since 1987, Epsilon is a pioneer and world leader in high performance composite materials thanks to the pultrusion process. This highly efficient technology combined with the extraordinary properties of carbon fibers is the ideal solution to manufacture the cores of advanced conductors, also known as High Capacity / High Temperature Low Sag () conductors. Thanks to their strong lightweight composite core, our advanced conductors allow to easily and cost-effectively double the ampacity of overhead lines, to mitigate sag issues and to reduce electrical losses, therefore cutting down on CO2 emissions and ensuring a quick return on investment for utilities. Finance Manager vs. Accounting Manager How are the duos different from each other? Understanding the distinct roles of finance and accounting managers is vital for any business aiming for efficient financial management. Here's a clear breakdown of their differences: [1] Role Focus: Finance Managers oversee strategic financial planning and investments. Accounting Managers handle day-to-day financial records and tax compliance. [2] Education: Finance Managers often hold MBAs for high-level strategic roles. Accounting Managers typically need a bachelor's in accounting, sometimes paired with a CPA. [3] Scope of Work: Finance Managers create broad financial strategies affecting the entire company. Accounting Managers ensure financial accuracy and regulatory adherence within the department. __ Whether forecasting future growth or managing current assets, both roles are essential to a business's financial stability and progress. Source: â€¦see more
The CMOâ€™s fate is sealed within ~30 days. And this comes down to one thingâ€¦ ğŸ‘‰ REPORTING. Truth is, thereâ€™s an abundance of data available to us today. And a whole bunch of metrics to try and make sense of it all. â€” â€œRevenue, NRR, CAC, payback period, churn, LTV, MQLs, SQOsâ€¦.â€ On and on we go. But theyâ€™re usually NOT defined. So, you have a situation where youâ€™ll be reviewing â€˜performanceâ€™ and a whole bunch of acronyms will be floating around the room. All with a hundred different definitions from Sales, the CFO, the CEO, the CMO, and everyone else in the room. And usually no one has any idea what theyâ€™re talking about. So, the groups leave the room *thinking* theyâ€™ve reached a conclusion, when theyâ€™re actually talking about different things. This is a BIG problem. And itâ€™s ultimately marketing that will pay the price when targets are not met and the goal posts keep changing. Far better, then, to document all of this BEFORE you execute. â€“ What are the business goals? â€“ Which metrics define success/failure? â€“ How do you define those metrics? â€“ Over which periods? â€“ Has this been documented? â€“ Has everyone signed off on this? â€“ Is there a central place where EVERYONE can see the numbers? The vast majority of projects fail due to a lack of one key element: design thinking. âœ… Let's break it down.ğŸ“Œ Design thinking is a problem-solving approach. â†³ It's about understanding the user's needs, generating ideas, prototyping, and testing solutions. â†³ It's not just about making things look good. â†³ It's about creating a product or service that works well and meets the user's needs. Why is it so important in your project? 1ï¸âƒ£ Empathy: Design thinking starts with understanding the user's needs. This ensures that your project is solving a real problem and not just an assumed one. 2ï¸âƒ£ Creativity: Design thinking encourages brainstorming and ideation. This leads to innovative solutions that might not have been considered otherwise. 3ï¸âƒ£ Iteration: Design thinking is an iterative process. You prototype, test, and refine your solution until it's just right. This reduces the risk of project failure. Recently, I completed a formation on design thinking. I learned about the importance of empathy, creativity, and iteration in problem-solving. I also learned how to apply these principles to my projects. Since then, my approach to projects has changed. I now start with understanding the user's needs. I brainstorm and prototype solutions. I test and refine these solutions until they're just right. Just Remember Design thinking is not just a buzzword. It's a powerful problem-solving approach that can make your projects more successful. So, if you're not already using design thinking in your projects, start now. You won't regret it. Big Thanks ğŸ’¥ â€¦voir plus Voir la traduction

The difference between a successful mind and a failure mind could be as simple as this one habit.âœ… It's all about perspective. A successful mind sees challenges as opportunities. It embraces the unknown and learns from mistakes. On the other hand, a failure mind views obstacles as insurmountable. It fears change and dwells on past errors. Now, let's dive deeper. A successful mind cultivates a growth mindset. It believes in the power of hard work and perseverance. It understands that failure is part of the process, not the end of the road. Contrarily, a failure mind harbors a fixed mindset. It believes that abilities are static and unchangeable. It sees failure as a reflection of self-worth, not as a stepping stone to improvement. But here's the kicker. You can transform a failure mind into a successful one. How? By changing your perspective. â†³ Start by embracing challenges instead of avoiding them. â†³ Learn from your mistakes instead of dwelling on them. â†³ Believe in your ability to grow and improve. Out of BOUNDS (Why tension is important in #BUSINESS) When I need to close a deal, I am always looking for tension. If you think of tension as a good thing, then you will know that in the game of tug of war (or modern-day business), if the other side isn't holding the rope, no one is interested in your deal, LOL. Tension is seen as bad, but it tells both sides the truth about a deal and is crucial as then I know what pain points I need to alleviate to get the deal across the finish line. Do you know what tension hates? Consensus, LOL. Not all parties will agree on everything, and neither will your own internal team. How do I get better at creating TENSION, Ahmad? 1) Craft your questions with ...For example, I see we have lost 5% in EBITDA in the last five years...What can we do to add a 10% increase in EBITDA in the next two years? You called out a red flag and then proposed a target. Again, tension is to make things more transparent, not adversarial...Think of it as a breakthrough vs. Mike Tyson breaking through, LOL. Jake Paul don't want any of Mikey, LOL. 2) EMBRACE TENSION - The other side feels better when they know you will put your hand in the fire with them. It creates trust. However, most firms are so worried about creating a negative sentiment that they lose depth and trust with the counterparty. 3) RED FLAGS - I like to pick FIVE things that really bother me, then pick three things I need to take to the board. I don't bring them 20 red flags, only my most important to get the deal done. Last week, a PE associate brought 38 red flags to the deal; we didn't do the DEAL, LOL. Succession HOPES this HELPS YOU. Follow: â€¦voir plus Voir la traduction

Feeling stuck can happen to the best of us. But what if we saw challenges as exciting starting lines instead of roadblocks? Here are 6 ways I personally tested out to jump right in and get moving (without the stress!): ğŸ‘‰ The 5-Second Rule: Overthinking can paralyze you. Count down from 5, and then just start! This quick burst of action gets you moving before your brain can talk you out of it. ğŸ‘‰ The ACT Technique: Feeling intimidated? Use the power of ACT: Accept the challenge, Choose a small step, Take action! This turns your fears into concrete steps forward. ğŸ‘‰ The 2-Minute Rule: Big tasks can feel overwhelming. Start with just 2 minutes! Often, that's all it takes to break the ice and get going. Suddenly, that big task doesn't seem so scary anymore. ğŸ‘‰ Embrace the Non-Zero Day: Do something, anything, related to your goal every day, no matter how small. Every little bit adds up and keeps you moving in the right direction. Consistency is key! ğŸ‘‰ The Timer Trick: Focus can be fleeting. Set a timer for 25 minutes of work followed by a 5-minute break. Knowing you have dedicated work periods helps you stay focused and avoid distractions. ğŸ‘‰ Do a Fear-Setting Exercise: What's the worst that could happen? Write it down and plan for it. Now, you can face your fears head-on, knowing you have a strategy to overcome them. Remember, success isn't just about giant leaps. It's about the small, consistent actions you take every day. So, what are you waiting for? 5, 4, 3, 2, 1... Go! P.S. My personal pick is The Timer Trick (works miracles), and yours? ğŸ¤” â€¦voir plus Voir la traduction

This guy is a secret weapon... This weekend, I flew out from the UAE to Belgium to attend Ilyes's wedding. He is my cousin and also my career booster. âš¡ In fact, we are career boosters for each other. We can say that we are career teammates. He is an amazing electrical engineer and project engineer. What does it mean to be a career booster? ğŸŠ We celebrate all professional and personal achievements. Every week, we bring a work challenge to overcome. This is really powerful as you get honest feedback on your work and, therefore, a better solution. No lies, No politics, Straight to the point. ğŸ¯ ğŸš¨ Whenever I have an urgent issue he can solve, I call him and usually get a solution in no time. I recommend finding your career booster; it doesn't have to be a family member. It could be a mentor, a colleague, a friend... Someone who truly supports you and gives you honest insights to improve your career. You will get: - Honest feedbacks on your work and strategies. - A continuous boost of energy. - A machine to generate ideas and solutions. Mastering the 'Approach Close' in Self-Defense Against Sales Messages!** ğŸš¨ Hey everyone! ğŸŒŸ Ever feel like you're under siege from a relentless barrage of sales messages? Whether it's your inbox, social media feeds, or even those sneaky in-store pitches, it's like everyone's out to sell you something! But fear not, fellow warriors of the digital ageâ€”I'm here to introduce you to the ultimate self-defense technique: the **"Approach Close."** ğŸ›¡ï¸ What is the Approach Close? The Approach Close is a cheeky ye sales to combat sales messages head-on. Itâ€™s all about taking control of the conversation, setting clear boundaries, and turning the tables on those persistent sellers. Think of it as your sales kryptonite! Step 1: Recognize the Signs First, you need to spot the sales message. Here are a few red flags: - Subject lines like "Exclusive Offer Just for You!" - DMs from strangers saying, "Hey, can I ask you something?" - Pop-up ads that promise, "You won't believe this deal!" Step 2: The Friendly Deflection When you recognize the approach, respond with a friendly but firm deflection. For example: Sales Message: "Hey! Have you heard about our amazing new product?" You: "Hey there! I appreciate the enthusiasm, but I'm currently focused on decluttering my life. Any tips on that?" ğŸ˜„ By shifting the conversation to something they didn't expect, you keep it light-hearted while taking control. Step 3: The Tactical Close Next, employ the tactical close. Politely let them know you're not interested, and provide a clear reason if you wish: Sales Message: "This product will change your life!" You: "That sounds incredible, but I'm actually on a strict budget right now, focusing on saving for my dream vacation. Maybe next time!" This approach shows respect for their effort but firmly closes the door on the current pitch. Why It Works The Approach Close is effective because it: - Sets Boundaries: Clearly indicates your disinterest without being rude. - Redirects Focus: Shifts the conversation to something non-sales related, giving you control. - Leaves a Positive Impression: Uses humor to keep the interaction friendly and memorable. Here is an example Imagine youâ€™re at a networking event, and someone starts pitching their latest product. Instead of feeling trapped, you use the Approach Close: Pitcher: "Our new software will revolutionize your business operations!" You: "Thatâ€™s fascinating! Iâ€™m actually knee-deep in a major project right now. Any advice for balancing work and self-care? I could use some tips!" The pitcher is now thinking about self-care strategies instead of continuing the sales pitch. You've effectively steered the conversation away from a hard sell while keeping it friendly. Happy deflecting! ğŸ›¡ï¸âœ¨ â€¦see more

ğŸŒ ClearBlue Markets Supports EcoLinks' Clean Cooking Project in Ghana: A Milestone in Climate Cooperation ğŸŒ ClearBlue Markets is proud to announce our collaboration with in developing and commercializing their transformative clean cooking project in Ghana. As the technical carbon advisor, ClearBlue will help guide this significant initiative. The ambitious project aims to distribute 100,000 high-efficiency charcoal-based cookstoves, replacing traditional three-stone stoves. This will promote cleaner cooking methods and significantly reduce air pollution and carbon emissions, leading to a healthier environment for all. Following the successful primary stakeholder consultation, we are thrilled to share the enthusiastic feedback and support we received from the community. Emmanuel Otoo, a local farmer from Amisano, shared his experience: "My mother received a cookstove in the pilot project. That's when I understood the importance of the cookstove and saw improvement in the community." The recent implementation agreement between Ghana and Singapore is a significant milestone in international cooperation in the fight against climate change. EcoLinks' project has received pre-authorization from the government of Ghana's Carbon Market Office for trading under Article 6.2 of the Paris Agreement. This agreement not only allows Singaporean companies to invest in Ghana but also paves the way for enhanced international collaboration. The project is currently under preliminary review for Gold Standard certification. Sunday Perspective: Expertise Over Influence in Enterprise Sales... Good morning, and welcome to my Sunday Sales Perspective. I'm Ed Golod. Today, we look into the complex world of enterprise sales and the growing influence of LinkedIn consultants. â¡ï¸The Phenomenon of LinkedIn Influencers: LinkedIn has become a beacon of knowledge-sharing, allowing anyone with a compelling story to reach millions. While this democratization of information is commendable, it has also led to a landscape where advice is plentiful, but depth is just not there. Many LinkedIn influencers, though well-intentioned, offer insights based on limited experience. The reality of enterprise sales is not a novice sport. â¡ï¸Understanding Enterprise Sales complexities. Selling to Fortune 500 companies with deeply complex and political execs. means you have to sell as a peer. Gartner says "average buying groups for complex B2B solutions have 6-10 decision-influencers, and 6-12 mos. to close. This is not for the faint of heart. â¡ï¸The Journey to Expertise Becoming a doctor takes 14 years + 10 years in practice. Attorneys take 7 years and 10 years in cases. Structural engineers take 8 years + 15 years of work experience. So how is it the volumes of Sales advisors cannot rise to these levels? â¡ï¸Why the Gap Exists LinkedIn's algorithm rewards visibility and engagement, favoring sensational, easily digestible content over detailed insights. This allows individuals with limited experience to gain significant followings quickly, offer advice and make a living. But, stepping into a boardroom at a Fortune 500 company and closing a deal? Thatâ€™s an entirely different ball game. These influencers arenâ€™t to blame. Theyâ€™re doing the best they can with the experience they have. However, selling into large enterprises requires building trust with senior executives, navigating complex decision-making hierarchies, and providing comprehensive, financial value propositions+. This takes decades of experience and hundreds of meetings to master. â¡ï¸Real-World Experience Matters For many with decades in the field, handling $100's of millions in sales and countless deals, the path to success was clear but brutal. We had to master complex tech, value building, competitive battles, finance, CEO power...and countless more. â¡ï¸What Can You Do? If youâ€™re serious about mastering complex enterprise sales, start with: #1 Value Workshop: map your ICPs, GTMs, ASP, Exec pain, strategic priorities...to your solution's value. #2 Hyper-personalized Messaging/Positioning: for relevancy for trust. #3 In-Field Analysis: to learn on a daily basis. #4 Deal Roadmaps: that guide across the finish line. #5 And 30-50 more parameters... Mastering winning is a journey, not a destination. Thanks for joining on this Sunday Perspective. Until next time, the p What's your point of view? â€” â€¦see more

B2B marketing isn't rocket science. But it's hard to know where to start. Here's a simple method I've used that works: 1. Create Demand If you're not getting questions, you're not creating demand. - Help with a one-off problem - Offer lead magnets, for free - Provide tutorials Plant the seed. Provide value. Don't actively pitch. You have now created a demand. 2. Start Dialogue Go talk to them, actively. - Invite them to events - Invite them to a podcast - Actively ask them questions - Answer to comments, replies, questions,... This establishes trust, showcases your expertise, and encourages conversation. 3. Capture Demand Now and only now is the time to sell to them. - Offer solutions to their problems. - Show them how you can help. - Create a next step and make it easy. Don't leave anything up to chance. This simple approach has helped me generate quality leads consistently. Give it a try and tell me how it goes! â€¦see more
Email design is absolutely not the thing that moves the needle in email marketing. To squeeze more money out of your list, focus on this. Focus on writing. Or even better, focus on SHOWING why you're product works. â€¦see more

Email Marketing Benchmarks: Gauging Performance with Key Metrics ğŸ“§ğŸ“Š Email marketing is a powerful tool in any marketer's arsenal, but knowing how well your campaigns are performing requires understanding key benchmarks. Here are some essential metrics to gauge your email marketing success: 1. Open Rate ğŸ“¬ The open rate is the percentage of recipients who open your email. A healthy open rate typically ranges from 15% to 25%, depending on your industry. Factors influencing this include subject lines, timing, and your audienceâ€™s engagement level. 2. Click-Through Rate (CTR) ğŸ–±ï¸ The CTR measures the percentage of email recipients who clicked on one or more links within your email. An average CTR ranges from 2% to 5%. To boost this, ensure your content is relevant and your calls-to-action (CTAs) are compelling. 3. Conversion Rate ğŸ’° Conversion rate is the percentage of email recipients who completed a desired action, such as making a purchase. A good conversion rate varies widely by industry but generally falls between 1% and 5%. High-quality content and personalized offers can improve this metric. 4. Bounce Rate ğŸš« This metric shows the percentage of your emails that couldnâ€™t be delivered. A healthy bounce rate should be below 2%. Regularly cleaning your email list and ensuring you have valid email addresses can help keep this low. 5. Unsubscribe Rate âŒ The unsubscribe rate indicates the percentage of recipients who opted out from your email list. Aim for a rate below 0.5%. High unsubscribe rates can signal that your content isnâ€™t resonating with your audience or that youâ€™re sending emails too frequently. 6. List Growth Rate ğŸ“ˆ This metric tracks how fast your email list is growing. A positive growth rate is crucial for maintaining a healthy email marketing program. Aim for a steady growth rate, factoring in new subscribers and unsubscribes. Monitoring these benchmarks will help you understand your email marketing performance and make data-driven improvements. Happy emailing! âœ‰ï¸âœ¨ â€¦see more

Still fixated on personas? If so, you're missing out. We've surveyed over 1,000 B2B IT decision makers globally and 77% of Sr. IT Executives and Management said staff have more involvement in the purchase process than they used to. I get it. We all want to talk to C-suites and get the buy-in from the very top right away. Unfortunately, only about one-in-three of senior business leaders get involved in the tech purchase process at the early-to-mid stages. You know who does though? IT staff, analysts, and specialists. 65% of them get in the buying process early, consuming awareness and research type of content before anyone else in the organization makes any decision. 70% of IT managers, directors, and architects do too. So if your persona targeting revolves around C-levels and VPs, yet your content is all about awareness, you're not talking to the people you should. Staff have a seat at the table and you should tailor to them accordingly. ğŸ¨ Image by DALLÂ·E 3 / Microsoft Copilot. â€¦see more

Statisticians love a good normal distribution! ğŸ“ˆ This familiar bell curve depicts how data is often distributed in the real world. The center of the curve represents the most common values, and the tails on either side represent less frequent values. Normal distributions are useful for understanding and predicting a wide variety of phenomena, from heights and weights to test scores and stock prices. â€¦see more

In B2B business, selling is only a means to an end, yet many salespeople treat it as the goal, leading to poor performance. 1. Selling is a means because it initiates the process of value co-creation. 2. Selling is a means because if the product sold is of no value to the customer, it can result in negative returns. 3. Selling is a means because there are other ways to enhance corporate value beyond sales. Sales teams that focus solely on selling will fail. Overemphasis on sales can lead to negative growth due to bad reviews and brand damage. Therefore, customer communication should not be solely aimed at making sales. â€¦see more

How LinkedIn used cold email to sign a multi-billion dollar contract with Google It's 2022, and LinkedIn is on a mission to take its job matching game to the next level. They know they need something special to wow their users. Meanwhile, Google is sitting on a gold mine with its Natural Language API - a tool that can analyze text and extract insights like nobody's business. But there's a problem. Google needs a high-profile test case to show the world what its API can really do. Enter LinkedIn, with a daring plan to cold outreach their way into a partnership: âœ… They spotted the opportunity â€” LinkedIn saw how Google's API could supercharge their job matching and create a more personalized experience for users. It was a match made in tech heaven. âœ… They came prepared â€” LinkedIn didn't just pitch the idea - they came armed with data on how the integration would boost engagement and satisfaction. They made an offer Google couldn't refuse. âœ… They addressed concerns head-on â€” Google had doubts about data privacy and the technical challenges of integration. LinkedIn tackled these objections with clear plans and assurances, leaving no stone unturned. âœ… They painted a picture of mutual success â€” LinkedIn showed Google how the partnership would be a win-win. Google would get a high-profile showcase for its tech, while LinkedIn would get a major competitive edge. Together, they'd be unstoppable. The result? Google took the leap. The integration was a smash hit. LinkedIn users raved about the hyper-relevant job matches. Engagement soared. And Google? They basked in the glory of showing the world what their API could do. Other businesses lined up to get a piece of the action. The takeaways for your cold outreach: âœ… Look for opportunities to create massive value âœ… Come armed with data that makes your case irresistible âœ… Anticipate and preemptively counter any objections âœ… Paint a picture of shared success that excites your prospect That's how you forge game-changing partnerships out of thin air. Take a page out of LinkedIn's playbook and swing for the fences with your next cold outreach. The results might just blow your mind. I know they did for me when I landed my biggest client ever with a single bold email. So go on, give it a shot. Fortune favors the bold! . . . P.S. Weâ€™ve helped clients generate $51.2 M in revenue and book 224,700 sales calls. If you need help growing your business, click here to learn more about how we can help: â€¦see more
While each one has a slightly different definition, all three terms are used to answer the same question. ğŸ‘‡ Who is my perfect customer? Understanding your perfect customer will help you build a successful business, create an on-target brand, and develop effective marketing. 1. Ideal Client Your ideal client benefits immediately from your product or service. They are frequent purchasers and great sources of word-of-mouth marketing, recommending your business to family and friends. Understanding your ideal client is essential for business success. 2. Ideal Client vs. Ideal Customer Is there a difference between an ideal client and an ideal customer? Not really. The terms vary by industry. Consultants have clients, while grocery stores have customers. 3. Avatar "Avatar" is shorthand for "ideal customer." You might hear "customer avatar," "ideal client avatar," or just "avatar." The term became more common with gaming profiles. 4. Buyer Persona Ideal Customer Profile and Buyer Persona are often used interchangeably but differ in two ways: a) A buyer persona is built by researching current customers, while an Ideal Customer Profile is a composite of your perfect customer. b) A well-developed buyer persona reveals what prospective customers think and do when considering your product or service. Understanding and identifying your perfect customer has a profound impact on your business. It allows you to tailor your products, services, and marketing efforts to meet their specific needs and preferences. ğŸ”ƒ If you found this post useful, please share it with your network. Follow for more marketing and sales insights. â€¦see more

The BEST way to increase your client LTV is through consistent communication. Here's four ways to take client communication to the next level: 1) Informal check-ins These are straightforward check-ins to see how their business is performing or how they're doing. We strive to make our clients feel valued beyond the services they hired us for. Never underestimate the power of asking, â€œHow has your week been?â€. 2) Weekly KPI updates Key Performance Indicator (KPI) check-ins are sessions where we update our clients on the progress of our services. Updates include: â†’ New strategies â†’ Implemented changes â†’ Current performance Clients hate being left in the dark and sending KPI updates will remove any fog and manage expectations effectively. 3) Holding clients accountable and repeating points We never assume our clients are converting positive responses from cold emails into booked calls, and more importantly, into clients. We follow up with our clients to ensure they are booking calls and closing deals, which contributes to their satisfaction with our services. Understanding their challenges allows us to adjust our strategies, reducing the likelihood of them churning. 4) Zoom calls We conduct four types of calls with our clients to meet their specific needs: â†’ Alignment calls when campaigns launch to ensure both parties are aligned for the future. â†’ DWY inbox management sessions where we teach clients how to effectively manage their inbox to respond to leads and book calls. â†’ Strategy pivot sessions in case we need to adjust our strategies, as no single strategy fits all. â†’ 1-on-1s with me and yes, Iâ€™m aware Iâ€™m a handsome guy that people want to talk to lol â€¦see more
In this week's edition of Tech Wrap-Up Europe, Sam Shead talks to Stripe co-founder and president John Collison about his journey from the small Irish village of Dromineer to building one of the world's most valuable private companies. Backed by the likes of Peter Thiel and Elon Musk, the company is today valued at around $65bn. But Collison says he and his co-founder Patrick (his brother), are in "no rush" to take the company public through an IPO. The fintech giant processed over $1tn of payments in 2023, which is around 1% of global GDP. It's continuing to expand in the UK, which is its second biggest market after the US, and elsewhere in Europe. In this interview, we talk about Stripe's journey, as well as artificial intelligence, crypto and a number of Collison's passion projects. We also look at the main hurdles that AI researchers need to overcome in order to reach the holy grail of artificial general intelligence, or AGI. What do you make of Stripe's rise? Share your thoughts in the comments below. â€¦see more
Sales is not for everyone. However there are different sales roles. If your current sales role isn't a good fit for you, there are several steps you can take to address the situation: Self-Assessment: Identify the Issues: Determine why the role doesn't suit you. Is it the nature of sales itself, the company culture, the product, or something else? Assess Your Strengths and Interests: Reflect on your skills, interests, and what you enjoy doing. This can help you identify a more suitable career path. Professional Development: Skill Improvement: If the issue is related to skills, consider taking courses or seeking mentorship to improve your sales techniques. Career Counseling: Speak with a career counselor to explore your options and get professional advice. Exploring Other Roles: Internal Transfers: Look for opportunities within your current company. There might be other roles that align better with your strengths. External Opportunities: Start exploring job opportunities outside your current company. Use job search engines, networking, and recruitment agencies. Networking: Connect with Professionals: Reach out to people in industries or roles you're interested in. Networking can provide insights and potential job leads. Attend Industry Events: Participate in industry conferences, seminars, and meetups to expand your network and learn about different roles. Resume and Interview Preparation: Update Your Resume: Highlight your transferable skills and experiences that are relevant to the new roles you're interested in. Prepare for Interviews: Practice common interview questions and be ready to explain why you're transitioning out of a sales role. Temporary Solutions: Freelancing or Part-Time Work: Consider freelancing or part-time jobs in fields of interest while you search for a full-time role. Side Projects: Engage in side projects or volunteer work to gain experience in the area you want to move into. Mental Health and Well-being: Stress Management: Ensure you are managing stress and maintaining your mental well-being during the transition. Seek Support: Talk to friends, family, or a therapist if you're feeling overwhelmed. Transitioning to a new role can be challenging, but it's also an opportunity to find a career that better matches your passions and strengths. â€¦see more

The biggest LinkedIn lie that's holding back your outreach (...and the truth you need to hear): "You need a huge following to succeed on LinkedIn." I've heard this countless times, and frankly, it's misleading. Here's the reality: Your follower count is meaningless if they're not your target audience. Even with 100,000 followers, if they're not the right people, your outreach will struggle to gain traction. âœ… Quality over quantity A focused, engaged audience of ideal clients is far more valuable than a large, generic following. Fish where your fish are. âœ… Create content for your niche Instead of trying to appeal to everyone, concentrate on your perfect prospects and create content that directly addresses their needs and pain points. Show them you understand their challenges. âœ… Personalize your outreach Generic "Hi {FirstName}" messages won't cut it. Research your prospects, identify their issues, and demonstrate how you can provide solutions. Make your outreach irresistible. âœ… Prioritize meaningful interactions The real opportunity lies in genuine conversations. Engage with your ideal clients, nurture authentic relationships, and watch your sales grow. That's where the true leverage is. I've witnessed people with modest follower counts achieve remarkable success on LinkedIn, simply by focusing on attracting and engaging the right audience. So instead of fixating on vanity metrics, concentrate on providing substantial value to your ideal clients. That's the secret to mastering LinkedIn outreach. . . . P.S. Competitive price models in B2B SaaS ğŸ“ˆ One thing that I'm really passionated about when I meet with leaders at different SaaS companies is to review their price models, and understand the strategy behind it - everyone I meet has such different approach to this. Below is some of the common themes I've observed from successful SaaS businesses: âœ… The pricing model is transparent. Not all pricing models are easy to understand, so achieving transparency and simplicity is key, even if your SaaS offering is complex. âœ… Their pricing models enable customers to scale, often incorporating a consumption or usage-based component. This approach is attractive to customers, as they only pay for what they use, and it also helps the business gain a larger market share. âœ… They revisit their pricing strategy and models once, sometimes twice a year, making adjustments as needed. Pricing isn't a one-time task - it needs to be an ongoing process to stay competitive and responsive to market changes. How often do you revisit your pricing strategy? â€¦see more
The root cause of the disconnect between setting business objectives and evaluation of marketing performance is Business objectives are set at the level of Industry Segments or Territories (essentially a set of accounts), but Marketing Measurement is primarily indexed on Channels or Campaigns. For instance, an enterprise company that we work with articulated its key business priorities as 1ï¸âƒ£ Drive adoption in Financial Services - a vertical where they are seeing green shoots 2ï¸âƒ£ Go up-market and focus on higher ACV deals within SaaS 3ï¸âƒ£ Improve Brand Awareness in the European Region For each of these Priorities, the marketing team planned Integrated Campaigns covering Paid Ads, Content, Events, Webinars and E-books. However, when it came to tracking progress against these segments, the existing tools really came up short. Last week, we launched Segment Insights within ( available to our Growth and Enterprise Plan customers). This feature allows a Marketing Team to track Marketing (MQLs, SQLs, Deals and Pipeline) and Sales Metrics (Revenue, ACV, Win Rate and Sales Cycle Length) for every Segment they have built inside our product. Further, they can compare these performance metrics over time or compare segments to understand differences in performance. Sharing a screenshot of how this looks inside . How To Grow Your Email List With Instagram The power of email marketing is undeniable. But, if you want to maximize the success of your email campaigns, you need to have a large email list to work with. Growing your email list can be difficult, but if youâ€™re active on Instagram, there are plenty of ways to take advantage of the platform to grow your list. ğŸ‘‰ 1. Promote Your Sign-up Link The most obvious way to grow your email list with Instagram is to promote your sign-up link. This can be done in a variety of ways, such as posting it in your bio, creating a post that highlights the link, or creating an Instagram Story that includes the link. ğŸ‘‰ 2. Run Contests Running contests is a great way to get people to follow your Instagram account, as well as sign up for your email list. You can use a third-party app to help you manage the contest, and make sure that everyone who enters also signs up for your email list. ğŸ‘‰ 3. Use Hashtags Hashtags are an incredibly powerful way to reach new audiences on Instagram. When creating posts, make sure to include relevant hashtags so that people can find your content more easily. You can also create a hashtag specifically for your email list, and use it to drive people to sign up. ğŸ‘‰ 4. Engage With Your Followers Engaging with your followers is a great way to build relationships and encourage them to sign up for your email list. Take the time to respond to comments and messages, and even feature fans in your posts. This will show them that youâ€™re listening and that you value their opinions. ğŸ‘‰ 5. Use Instagram Ads If you want to reach even more people, you can use Instagramâ€™s advertising platform to promote your email list. Instagram ads are incredibly effective, and theyâ€™ll help you reach a larger audience than you could with organic posts alone. Growing your email list can be difficult, but with the right strategies, you can use Instagram to reach new audiences and encourage them to sign up. By promoting your sign-up link, running contests, using hashtags, engaging with your followers, and using Instagram ads, you can grow your email list and maximize the success of your email campaigns. â€¦see more

Ever feel like your Amazon sales info is just a confusing mess? You're not alone! Lots of sellers feel lost at sea with all those numbers and reports. But guess what? That info can actually be your secret weapon to selling more stuff and keeping customers happy! Here's how: Find Your Gold: Imagine reports like treasure maps! They're basically like friendly pirates giving you advice! ï¸ See what they love and what they think could be better. This helps you make your listings even more awesome! Feeling overwhelmed by all that info? Here's a super easy trick: Instead of trying to understand everything at once, just pick a few reports that sound interesting. Our win rates increased by x% (at a past company) if several specific criteria were met. That's an observation we made after taking an out-of-the-box view at our data, and it led to a tangible change in our go-to-market approach. There were a number of criteria we observed. And while it was difficult for us to pinpoint exactly which ones made the biggest impact, the ones that seemed to be particularly important were: - if the buyer had been referred to us independently (i.e., we did not have role in the referral) - if our execs had developed relationships with theirs - if they had employees who used our products previously at a different organization These insights above taught us to spend more time cultivating relationships and developing independent customer advocacy. And even on the third point, there were things we could do to try to bias things in our favor (such as helping a customer who has been laid off to find a new job elsewhere.) This is an example of how having data-driven insights can lead to actionable changes in your GTM that go beyond just spending more money on ads, etc. It's a novel approach with tangible results. Have you ever analyzed your data in this manner or found similarly powerful insights? â€¦see more

Have you ever received an email that, at the start, makes you brace for bad news â€“ only for it to be something positive? Founder Wes Kao calls this confusing bait-and-switch "vaguely ominous" writing. She proposes the solution of "emotional signposting" â€“ giving cues that guide the audience to interpret the information as positive, negative or neutral upfront. This makes messages clearer and more resonant. Rather than inadvertently putting recipients on edge by burying the lede, emotional signposting allows you to lay helpful groundwork and smoothly steer them towards the intended takeaway. Do you find yourself frequently decoding vaguely ominous emails? How can writers improve their emotional signposting? â€¦see more

Do you actively seek out a company that cares about the environment when looking for a new job? What sustainability commitments would entice you? Climate policies are important to gen Z and millennials, with nearly half of younger workers (45%) saying they have already left a job, or plan to, because their company wasnâ€™t doing enough to protect the environment, a new global survey from has found. A quarter of younger workers surveyed also said they would study up on a potential employer's environmental policies before accepting a role. The report further reveals that climate concerns are a top priority, with 62% of gen Zs and 59% of millennials reporting feeling anxious or worried about climate change in the past month. These workers are also proactively pushing businesses to make better decisions. These initiatives include employee subsidies for sustainable choices, renovating office locations to be greener, offering more sustainable products or services and committing to net-zero greenhouse gas emissions by 2030. Does this sound like you? Vote in our poll below and tell us where you stand on this issue in the comments below. By Rachel Cromidas and Cathy Anderson Sources: : : â€¦see more

Email Marketing for B2B: Best Practices for Success ğŸ“§ğŸ’¼ Effective B2B email marketing hinges on personalization and relevance. Start by segmenting your email list to target specific industries, job roles, or company sizes. Craft compelling subject lines to capture attention and ensure your content is valuable, addressing pain points or offering solutions. ğŸ“ˆ Use a professional yet engaging tone, and always include a clear call-to-action (CTA). Regularly test and optimize your emails by experimenting with different designs, copy, and send times. ğŸ“Š Automation can streamline your campaigns, allowing you to send timely and personalized messages based on user behavior. Ensure your emails are mobile-friendly, as many professionals check emails on the go. ğŸ“± Lastly, analyze your results to refine your strategy continuously. Open rates, click-through rates, and conversions are key metrics to monitor. Successful B2B email marketing builds strong relationships and drives business growth. ğŸš€ Happy emailing! ğŸ“¨ â€¦see more
The art of persuasion in sales is no longer selling the product but understanding the opportunity that the product creates or the problem it solves. The B2B landscape has undergone a seismic shift in recent years, dramatically altering the dynamics between buyers and sellers. Today's B2B buyers are more informed, more independent, and more in control than ever before. To remain competitive, software and SaaS companies must adapt to these changes and focus on meeting buyers' needs rather than their own. Read on ğŸ‘‡ â€¦see more
You know the way your buyers buy has changed, and your playbooks don't work anymore. But leadership (and, eventually, sales) don't want to accept the reality and change. Here are 3 layers of proof and reasoning we use to change that mindset: 1. BUYER JOURNEY OF EXISTING CLIENTS. Start with interviewing recent closed won deals. - How did they become aware of you? - Did they check any marketing content before becoming a client? - What internal discussions did they have and how they presented your product? - Why did they decide to buy? - How they typically do vendor research and evaluation? Collect and present different touchpoints. 2. CURRENT PLAYBOOKS' PERFORMANCE. Analyse revenue, pipeline, pipeline velocity and revenue metrics Average Contract Value Win rate Sales cycle length # of sales opportunities (not discovery calls) Expansion deals Payback Account to pipeline ratio (how many accounts that were targeted became sales opportunities) for the last 36 months. Next, analyze and categorize lost reasons. Then, create diagrams to present declining pipeline and revenue. 3. INDUSTRY CASE STUDIES. Interview or talk to consultants and marketing agencies that work with your industry, or non-competing companies that made a change you want. - Why did they decide to make a change? - What are their core activities and why do they run them? - Before / after results ---- Change management is hard. You can do it only with data and social proof. But don't stop here. Wrap up everything in a short presentation explaining WHY to change now, your suggested transformation and a detailed pilot program. --- This Thursday we invited our client to share how he was able to make the change management and transform Go-To-Market strategy of . As a result, in 6 months the marketing-sourced pipeline went from 35% to 60%. Save your spot here: â€¦see more

Sales teams - please STOP blaming Marketing for bad leads I see too many companies bringing in a Head of Marketing to generate leads And then be disappointed by spammy, poor quality, poor-fit, too-early leads That just waste everyone's time. Marketing is doing the job you asked of them. (That's Step 1) BUT there's something key missing At the COMPANY that is causing this misalignment. Now it's time for Step 2: Add a Scoring Model to your systems to weed out the best-fit leads from the chaff. - Redefine the MQL threshold (maybe it should be higher) - Set up the buying unit's Personas in your CRM - Add your behavior Scoring Model to the CRM - Add your ICP match Scoring Model to the CRM - Add your Target Account list to the CRM + Bonus Points: Add a gated demo on your website (Try , , or if you're a startup, or if you're more established) -Create reports that prove lead quality (based on the above) - Create routing rules in your systems: --Send poor-fit leads a "sorry we're not the best fit - here are some resources instead" email --Place okay-fit leads on nurture outreach sequences (for later) --Route great-fit leads to a Sales demo The main reason why the misalignment happened is because the teams never agreed on "good lead" criteria. And didn't program it (using quantifiable, measurable attributes) in your systems Didn't battle-test and confirm it with reality Didn't create the charts and reports MEASURING lead quality. Create Sales & Marketing alignment, and generate more revenue, quicker - with the right leads for you. â€¦see more
Should employers and employees reinvent the (bicycle) wheel? Monday 3 June was World Cycling Day, celebrating a simple means of transportation that has been around for more than two centuries. Cycling is also one of the most sustainable ways to get around, with bikes being a clean, simple and long-lasting product. As such, encouraging more people to cycle could be a gamechanger for the climate. In the Netherlands, people cycle an average of 2.6 kilometres per day and use their bike for one in four trips. If that became the global standard, the world would see carbon emissions decrease by 686 million tonnes - that's more than the entire carbon footprint of Germany or the UK. Biking is also a great way to get in some daily exercise and boost your health. Compared to a non-active commute, cycling to work has been found to lower the risk of cancer and heart disease by 45% and 46%, respectively. Bike-to-work schemes are therefore a great way for employers to boost their sustainability credentials and keep their workforce healthy. Belgium, the Netherlands, France and some Italian cities including Florence and Bari are literally paying people to commute by bike, as workers receive a "mileage allowance" for every kilometre they cycle to work and back. While paid by businesses, employers can deduct this money from their tax bill. One in five people employed by Belgian small and medium-sized enterprises earned this bicycle allowance in the first half of 2022, reports. Elsewhere, policies are intended to lower the cost of cycling equipment. Luxembourg residents who ride their bike to work can deduct up to â‚¬300 from their personal income tax and use that money to buy a new two-wheeler. In the UK, it's more common for workers to acquire a bike through their employer and get part of the money back in tax deductions. âœï¸ Sources: â€¦see more
95% of customers read online reviews before buying a product 94% say reviews have made them avoid a business Google hosts 73% of all online reviews for businesses - Focus on Google Reviews - Encourage Positive Reviews From Customers - Engage with Feedback - Monitor Regularly â€¦see more

ğŸ” "Go Small in Large Accounts" â€“ The Game-Changer for Tech Sales! ğŸ’¡ Attention Sales Leaders and Professionals in Tech! ğŸš€ Are you looking to maximize your impact within large accounts? Brad Pitt and I are not dating. And your leads are not deals. I've identified Brad as a lead...but does Brad know who I am? Has he agreed to talk to me or take me on a date? No! The same is true of your fantasy prospective customers. I absolutely encourage you to build a list of these target companies and people, but they are not 'deals' until someone responds with the intent to learn more or buy. Pipeline structure and management are two of the biggest things I see so many startups get wrong. And it's not that hard to get right. âŒ They create deals (aka opportunities) when they identify a lead....not when someone has actually expressed interest and intent to buy. âŒ Their deal stages are a mess. They have too many stages, or they have a stage for 'on hold' where deals go to die, which throws off their conversions. âŒ They have 45 pipelines ğŸ¤¯ âŒ They don't consistently move deals through the funnel using objective exit criteria or put bumper rails in place to hold people accountable. âŒ They don't consistently track key data on their deals that helps inform their forecast or future refinement of positioning, targeting, marketing, and more. You don't need a big budget or 12 tools for this. You need 1 tool - a CRM. And you need to clearly document your sales stages with objective exit criteria and systematically hold people accountable to follow the process as designed. That's it. That's all you have to do to obtain meaningful pipeline metrics that should inform so many critical aspects of your go-to-market. This also should* be something you get right from the very. beginning. of. time. Starting with your founder led sales motion. You'll thank me later. This is what I'm talking about ALL month long in my newsletter. Get on da list. ğŸ‘€ ________________________ If you don't know me well, I'm Jess ğŸ‘‹ . Fractional CRO + CMO and Transition expert. Making go-to-market simple(r) and scalable for and sales reps, one at a time. â€¦see more

There are 2 ways to run B2B ads: The easy way (Identify a channel and launch ads as quickly as possible). The hard way (Conduct extensive customer research and then launch). Ironically, the easy way is the hard way. Youâ€™ll end up launching ads based on assumptions, running around in circles, and ultimately throwing money down the drain. Then you'll blame your failure on channels, creatives, copy, the market, etc. The hard way is the easy way. It starts, and ends, with your customer. Itâ€™s as simple as that. â€¦see more

Salespeople ğŸš€ 1ï¸âƒ£ Avoid creating false urgency on cold calls; you can't control the prospect's timeline. 2ï¸âƒ£ Pushing for meetings often backfires; focus on sparking interest instead. 3ï¸âƒ£ Ask when the issue you solve will become a higher priority for the prospect. 4ï¸âƒ£ Let prospects share their timeline to understand their needs better. 5ï¸âƒ£ This approach shifts you from being a pest to an informed seller, making prospects more likely to engage and buy from you. â€¦see more

As an email marketing agency, we send a lot of emails across clients (15 Million last year, and on track to almost double that this year). By far the biggest element in successful email marketing is deliverability: If emails aren't reaching your audience, then it doesn't matter what the offer is or how well it was designed. Here's a blog post we wrote a few months ago: What happens when you click send. I wrote this because I think when you understand the journey an email makes, the whole topic of deliverability starts to make sense. And the best news: is that there are fixes at every step along the way and that deliverability is entirely solvable. Hope you enjoy it! In 2000, Palm was valued higher than Apple, Amazon, Google, and Nvidia all together > Palm pioneered the personal digital assistant (PDA) market with the PalmPilot. The PalmPilot featured a calendar, address book, and memo pad, making it popular among professionals and tech enthusiasts. > Palm developed its own operating system, Palm OS, known for its intuitive interface and efficient use of memory. > Palm's market capitalization reached $58 billion. > 10 years later, Palm struggled to adapt to the rise of smartphones with touchscreens and internet access. The company's slow adoption of new technologies led to a loss of market share. Palm brand was discontinued in August 2011. > The story of Palm serves as a reminder that today's tech leader can become tomorrow's trivia answer. It also emphasizes the transient nature of success in the tech industry. How can we make ourselves and our organizations become IRREPLACEABLE? Join our new Academy & Community: â€¦see more

The worst sales email I've seen started like this.... Hi. My name is [FRIST NAME]. I work for [Company], and we [INSERT SOLUTION]. YIKES! Years ago, I worked at a startup selling a SaaS solution to companies that didn't necessarily know they needed our software. I was able to close deals with , , and large consulting firms. Why? I helped them solve problems that they couldn't solve on their own. Most of all, I made it about them. You can do the same thing with a sales email. Start with them. For example... Instead of "Hi, my name is Steve. I work for Joe's Software," try... "Hey, Bob. Congrats on the recent acquisition." "Hey, Bob. Your presentation about X resonated with me. [insert question]" "Hey, Bob. ICYMI, this WSJ article is exactly what you said in our call." "Hey, Bob. When we spoke, you said X. Thought this might be of interest." There are a ton of great strategies out there for email. That said, what's always worked for me is to start with them - not me. Any other ideas or thoughts? What strategies and techniques have worked for you? â€¦see more
Could This Be Why You're Being Ghosted? A Tale of Winging It vs. Planning Imagine you're setting sail on a bright, sunny day. The sea is calm, the wind is perfect, and you're ready for an adventure. You decide to wing itâ€”no plan, just following your instincts. Sounds thrilling, right? But what happens when the weather suddenly changes? Without a plan, you're left reacting to the waves, hoping your instincts will guide you to safety. More often than not, you end up off course, struggling to regain control. In sales, winging it feels naturalâ€” 98% of reps do it. It's intuitive and doesn't require much thought. But here's the brutal truth: it usually doesn't work. Think about it. When you wing it, you react instead of being proactive. You end up doing what the client wants, like sending a proposal without understanding their real needs. And 95% of the time, they ghost you. Why? Because there's a lot of courage required to come with suggestions of buying these days. Who really wants to take a risk on how they'll be seen if an initiative they brought fails? Status quo feels safer, which is exactly why we're hereâ€”to identify the reasons behind their requests and navigate them to what will truly help them make the desired change. So how do you stop being ghosted after proposals? It all starts by measures- as each action needs to be compare against: Step 1: Analyze how all conversations that asked for a proposal have landed. Step 2: Test how much time you invest in setting a proposal out. Step 3: Ask your buyers what exactly they expect to see in the proposal. Step 4: Run a report on all the answers you get and make sure you address those queries proactively in your next meetings. Step 5: Analyze the results and compare. Before the change, 60% of the buyers we shared a proposal with didn't move forward. Can you guess what the outcome was after we followed these steps? â€¦see more

Top Strategies for Generating Qualified B2B Leads: - Cold calling no longer cuts it - Decision-makers want personalized content - Quality over quantity when it comes to leads - Automation can streamline but not replace human touch Sticking to old methods is impractical â€“ it means: - Not understanding evolving buyer demands - Failing to innovate - Missing a solid long-term plan Hereâ€™s what you MUST do to generate qualified B2B leads: - Deeply know your target market; - Tailor your strategy to fit the buying journey; - Use focused tactics for effective lead generation. This is the (anti-)pattern and I see it in my own engineers at times (because it is human nature). A story about how UK Borders chose to in-house the successful post-Brexit border solution after 3 years because of budget pressure. It beggars belief to think that something vital can be done more cheaply in-house that a company does for a living with a massive amortized R&D base - meaning you pay some small fraction of the actually costs of development and operations. Yesterday I learned the origin of Platform One was an effort to avoid paying $19M/year in licenses to a platform-as-a-service company (and to avoid feeling locked-in). Now Platform One is ~150 FTEs (~$50-70M/year est cost fully loaded and now your are mentally and technically locked-in). It happens as much in the commercial world as the government world. But in the commercial world, your competitors will pounce upon your folly and strike (see Predix). That same feedback loop isn't present in Govt, and without it I think all Commercial companies would do exactly the same thing (human nature). We are re-deriving from first principles why the tech business model exists at all: massive R&D costs are amortized across a large number of customers to create affordability and scale. 's article, "Don't get locked up into avoiding lock-in", provides a more robust way to think about these decisions: And it is important to remember that the goal of Open Source was never to avoid lock-in -- it was funded to commoditize someone's compliments. â€¦see more
Remote working is one of the major reasons people want to switch careers to code. But it's not a good idea (edit: remote as in full wfh, including across multi timezones. I don't consider hybrid to be remote) Remote work takes a level of autonomy and skill that beginner programmers are unlikely to have. Plus the upsides are all personal and the downsides are all professional. Which is not a good way to start off a new professional career. Instead, I'd say look for remote coding roles after you've spent a few years learning as much as you can through direct interaction with experienced coders. If remote work is a preference and not a necessity, then park the preference for 2 years. Your future coder self will thank you. Feel free to ask my why in the comments! ğŸ‘‡ PS: I'm recording the latest episode of my podcast that summarizes my 13 years of flexible/hybrid and remote working experience. Watch out for that next week! â€¦see more

Amazon listing conversion tip: Did you know there's a section on the listing most brands neglect? It's a small section but leads to a massive lost in sales over time. It's the video section, right before the reviews and below the Q&A. If this section isn't filled with videos about your product, Amazon starts to fill it with competitors over time. Before you ask "Is this section even important?" In short, yes. We surveyed 100 Amazon customers in 2022 about this section. 48 said they look at this section when making a purchasing decision. When we pressed further, their general response "It's like YouTube product review, but I don't have to leave Amazon." Huge. And the good news? Anyone can upload here. Doesn't have to be a previous customer. Here's the better news. You can control this. Get your brand ambassadors / UGC content creators and tell them to upload it here. 5 videos minimum so competitor videos get pushed to second page. Small changes, big momentum. â€¦see more
ğŸ¤” What are the fundamentals of sales? Recently, I found myself reflecting on a discussion about the correlation between mastering the fundamentals and achieving better sales results. The consensus was clear: a solid grasp of the basics is indeed a stepping stone to enhanced sales performance. ğŸ¤¨ So, I was irked that the conversation was overly focused on specific skills and tools. A quick search on 'fundamentals of sales' confirmed my suspicion, with results emphasizing customer focus, prospecting, qualifying, and the like. ğŸ“– According to Webster, fundamental means "serving as an original or generating source." ğŸ‘‰ +Fundamentals are the foundation, not the skill itself. --- ğŸ¯ What the fundamentals of sales really are: 1. Supportive Beliefs: Beliefs shaped by upbringing influence sales behaviors and success. 2. Lack of Need for Approval: Fear of being disliked inhibits essential sales skills. 3. Ability to Control Emotions: Emotional involvement diverts focus from the present moment. 4. Supportive Buy Cycle: Your buying behavior influences your selling style. 5. Comfortable Discussing Money: Focus on value, not price. 6. Handling Rejection: A strong self-image helps one understand rejection is not personal. --- It's important to remember that both experienced and new salespeople often grapple with these fundamentals. You're not alone in this journey. The path to improving sales starts with mastering these basics. What's your take on these fundamentals? I'd love to hear your insights. ğŸ—¨ Comment, like, share, and ğŸ”” subscribe if you found this insightful! Your engagement is what makes this community thrive. â€¦see more

Why is CONTINUOUS sales enablement critical to scaling Cloud GTM? Kate K., Sr. Director, Global AWS Alliance at JFrog explained her 360 degree enablement strategy on the course hosted by Ongoing Seller Enablement is Key: âœ” Cloud marketplaces (MP) could be central to your company's success. They can help sellers close deals faster and meet or exceed quotas. However, cloud GTM is NOT a primary focus for sellers, who concentrate on their accounts and customers. âœ” Therefore itâ€™s Alliance leaders goal to ensure sellers grasp the benefits and importance of MPs. But how? Here are Kate's 10 Rules of Effective Sales Enablement: 1ï¸âƒ£ Regular and Continuous Efforts: Understand seller focus areas and keep cloud strategies top-of-mind without overwhelming their inboxes. Help them integrate cloud GTM early in sales cycle 2ï¸âƒ£ Go Beyond One-off Sessions: Include scheduled enablement calls, join QBRs, and maintain consistent communication. Ongoing sessions and follow-ups are vital to prevent â€œout of sight, out of mindâ€ issue 3ï¸âƒ£ Deliver Enablement in Various Formats: Use short on-demand videos, longer recordings, and in-person events to cater to different learning preferences 4ï¸âƒ£ Create Easy-to-Reference Guides: Create cheat sheets and central source of truth for sellers on key topics, e.g. â€œhow to co-sellâ€ or â€œGTM via MPsâ€ 5ï¸âƒ£ Establish Central Communication Channels: Use platforms like Slack to send Cloud GTM updates and facilitate collaboration and marketplace experience sharing among sales teams 6ï¸âƒ£ Provide Guidance for Co-Selling: Offer support on how to win in co-sell calls, including what questions to ask, how to show up, and what NOT to do 7ï¸âƒ£ Leverage Customer Stories and References: Use success stories to build credibility with sellers and get them excited. Compelling customer examples can help sellers internalize how MPs can expedite deal closures 8ï¸âƒ£ Identify and Leverage Successful Sellers as Advocates: Boost credibility by inviting sellers successful in Cloud GTM to share their stories in regular meetings. Developing internal advocates creates powerful peer influence. You can then across different motions or industry focuses can also be effective, ensuring relevance 9ï¸âƒ£ Conduct Research for Sellers: Gather insights to empower sellers before engaging in conversations with key stakeholders at the cloud provider 1ï¸âƒ£ 0ï¸âƒ£ Seek and Act on Feedback: Encourage open communication and actively incorporate feedback from sellers and sales leadership to support them where they need it the most Implementing ongoing sales enablement is essential for scaling Cloud GTM effectively. By integrating regular training, providing accessible resources, and fostering collaboration, you can get sales teams excited and aligned with MPs. This can help them meet quotas, make customers more successful and significantly contribute to company growth. How are you enabling your sales teams to excel in Cloud GTM? â€¦see more

10 (Honest) Steps to Integrate AI Into Your Business 1. Start with your business goals. What is stopping you achieve them? Write those challenges down. (Problem-centricity not tech-centricity) 2. Appoint an AI Champion (if youâ€™re a small business) or AI Task Force (if youâ€™re bigger). Theyâ€™ll do all the steps below. 3. Do a temperature check - how are your people feeling about AI? Confused? Scared? Excited? Write any concerns down. 4. Now, get that list of challenges from step 1. See if there are any AI tools that can help. (future tools is a great start) 5. There are? Fab. Experiment. Test them. Properly. Push their limits, find where they break. 6. Go back to step 3â€™s list of concerns. Educate, motivate, reassure. Build excitement. Donâ€™t try and do this without the buy-in of your people. 7. Roll out one tool at a time. Not a huge, confusing armoury, just the one. 8. Incentivise play and experimentation with this tool: set challenges, gamify. 9. Measure everything: time saved, ROI, changes in peopleâ€™s feelings, glitches, limitations. Apply this learning to everything you do next. 10. Find the next challenge and the next tool. Remember, AI wonâ€™t help with everything. Once youâ€™ve mastered off the shelf tools, your next 3 steps are: - Building automated workflows of stacked tools - Building GPTs/Assistants - Building autonomous AI agents â€¦more on those soon. ğŸ’¬ Where are you in your AI journey? â“ Have I missed anything? In Norway, you are given â€œPublication Pointsâ€ for publishing. Now, one scientist has published 871 papers in 5 years. â€œScientific publications yields publication points, which the Ministry of Education use as basis for reallocation of funds between institutionsâ€. How points are calculated: 1. Publication weight: Journal gives 0.7-3 points, books: 5-8 points. 2. International co-authoring is x1.3 multiplier 3. Several institutions in one paper means the points are divided between them. I guess that collaborations are not encouraged. ğŸ“ Filippo is the Norwayâ€™s most productive researcher. He produces a new study every two to three days (on average). â€œHe has reportedly expressed aspirations to become Europeâ€™s most productive researcherâ€ - Retraction Watch. Now, as Retraction Watch says, Filippo is accused of: - publishing duplicate studies in multiple journals - including references to irrelevant studies - producing articles that contain keywords from advertisements from paper millsâ€ Steineide Refseth (librarian from INN University in Norway): â€œResearchers are evaluated too much based on how much they have published instead of the quality of what they have published, and that the Norwegian publication points system may have contributed to this.â€ An average scientist in Norway got 1.25 points in 2022. Filippo got 407 points from 2019 to 2022. ğŸ“ My thoughts: This is another example of â€˜overpublishingâ€™. Quantity goes first and foremost. Numbers â€˜winâ€™. But for what? For respect? For money? For impact? Even with a large group, publishing more than 20-30 papers per year makes little sense. Quality per paper drops. Big numbers mean less time spent on each study. Quality of PhD education drops. Students have to produce papers instead of deep research. The impact drops. When a study is spread out across lots of papers, it becomes too thin to notice. Scientist â‰  printing machine. There should be NO push to publish lots of papers. Not from funders, nor from universities. This is why funding policies are so central to HOW and WHAT we publish.
