The founders of fast-growing European startups often get asked if they plan to relocate their headquarters to the US to tap into deeper pools of capital and talent. , the CEO of autonomous driving startup , is no exception. Last month, his London-headquartered startup raised $1bn from investors including , and ('s parent company). Since then, several journalists have asked him if he's going to move the company to Silicon Valley, or somewhere else. "Our headquarters is of course remaining and staying in London," Kendall said at on Monday. "I love the environment here," he added. "The thing that's special about London for me is that it's a tech superpower but it's not tech dominated. It's diverse, it's culturally rich. Almost a third of my company, including me, are here on a visa." Wayve currently has offices in London, Silicon Valley and Vancouver, and Kendall said it's likely to expand further in order to support the automotive partnerships the company has. "That footprint needs to be global to address the world," said Kendall, who moved from New Zealand to complete a PhD at the prior to setting up Wayve. Elsewhere, AI lab DeepMind (now owned by Google) is another UK tech startup that chose not to relocate to Silicon Valley, despite pressure from early investors like PayPal billionaire Peter Thiel. In France, has kept its HQ in Paris after raising large sums. On the other hand, four French unicorns â€“ , , and â€“ shifted their HQs to the US, according to analysis. Algolia, a B2B software company, moved its main base to San Francisco in 2014 to participate in the acceleration programme. Co-founder and CTO told Sifted it helped his company raise money at better terms and attract more customers. , the Irish born co-founder of , told LinkedIn News last month that top tech startups can raise money from investors regardless of where they're headquartered. "If you have a good startup idea, you're going to be able to raise money for it," he said. What can the UK and Europe do to ensure the most promising tech firms stay put? Random offers aren't the way to revenue stability Throwing random offers out there when you need a quick cash injection? I know you want more sales, but pumping out offer after offer isn't the secret. My guess is you sell some spots, feel on top of the world, just for it to come crashing down when the offer comes to a close. Because now you have to do it all AGAIN. You see other coaches throw out offer after offer and having huge success, so that must be the secret, right? Itâ€™s not. Understanding sales is crucial if you want to sell out your offers, every single time. If consistency and predictability in your income is what you want, then this is what you need to do: 1. Look at the bigger picture. Think about what you do and how you can solve your clientâ€™s problems in different ways. Look at it as stepping stones from point a-b. This will be the foundation for building a scalable (and sellable) offer suite. You need to know HOW to sell, WHEN to sell and WHERE to sell. ğŸ’¸Different platforms require different sales approaches. ğŸ’¸Each offer demands a tailored selling strategy. ğŸ’¸You can't share identical content across all channels and expect the same success. 2. Stop focussing on quick cash injections and prioritize your monthly recurring revenue. This is NOT only in the form of payment plans. A good strategy for MRR should include ways for you to sell without posting 50x a day and selling your soul on 100-story sequences or launching a new offer every month. Revenue pathways need to be prioritized. This includes: ğŸ’¸ Active offers ğŸ’¸ Passive/Evergreen offers ğŸ’¸ Sales Automations 3. Client retention: If youâ€™re just throwing out random offers that have no clear problem they solve or â€˜â€™next stepâ€™â€™ then your clients wonâ€™t know what to move into next. Having a clear pathway for clients to move through your offers will help you retain clients. And itâ€™s easier to sell to someone who has already bought than to get someone to buy for the first time. 4. Your sales strategy for your different offers. The way you create and sell a masterclass is different to how you sell a Mastermind. Selling private coaching requires a different strategy than selling a group program, or course. Selling on stories is different from selling on lives. Sales isn't a one-size-fits-all approach and those who tailor their sales according to WHAT they are selling and WHERE they are selling see the most success. The days of posting the same piece of content everywhere and crossing your fingers are over. If you want to make daily sales, you need to create a solid sales strategy for every offer. Full stop. And in Revenue on Repeat we cover all of this. You will walk away from ROR knowing EXACTLY what to do to make sales a daily thing. We start on July 17th. 27 people have claimed their spots, are you next? Lifetime access. A tailored strategy for whatever you're selling next so that you actually make sales. As a new B2B CMO or VP of Marketing your first 90 days are your most important. Here are 4ï¸âƒ£ key objectives for every new B2B marketing leader that both Nick Tippmann ğŸ”ï¸â˜ï¸ shares in his experience at , and what weâ€™re seeing on the agency side at . 1ï¸âƒ£ Due Diligence Do not confuse this with onboarding. Itâ€™s your responsibility to gain a deep understanding of brand narrative, product value, category insights, company profitability, sales metrics, and more. You cannot build a world-class marketing program with no benchmarks or context. 2ï¸âƒ£ Data Integrity Find out where marketing dollars and resources are going, measure the ROI, hit the killswitch on every marketing initiative not producing pipeline and ROI, and recover that wasted spend back to your marketing budget. 3ï¸âƒ£ MVP Experiments Your first win was recovering wasted spending back to the company. Your next win will come from making a strategic bet on a marketing initiative(s) and setting up benchmarks and roadmaps to validate it in the early stages. The worst mistake you can make as a new B2B marketing leader is betting the farm on a program with no positive signals or roadmap, and not hitting your target numbers. Instead, you should identify what positive signals validate a program in infancy, achieve those metrics, and then scale. 4ï¸âƒ£ Communication with Senior Leadership Most B2B marketing programs get shut down way too early because the marketing leader does not communicate all the factors to senior leadership. The program details are usually vague with a massive request for budget right after. The more clarity and depth you can bring to senior leadership on what and when to expect results will give you the breathing room needed to actually validate and scale your program. â€¦see more

Google's March 2024 Core Update: A Reckoning for Low-Quality Content & Spam The March 2024 Google Core Update is making waves, with some sites hit by manual actions or deindexing, while others remain unaffected. What's going on? Here's my take: Google is laser-focused on two things: - Low-quality content: AI-generated or not, content that lacks value and fails to provide information gain is being penalized. - Spam: From expired domain abuse to monetized spammy content, Google is cracking down hard. Who's at Risk? - Sites relying heavily on unvetted AI-generated content. - Sites with backlinks from dropped or spammy domains. - Sites monetizing unrelated third-party affiliate content. Have you been impacted? Check Google Search Console for significant drops in impressions and clicks since March 5th. Also, look for manual actions. What to do if you've been hit: - Assess the damage: Check GSC for deindexing or manual actions. - Identify the cause: Is it AI content, backlinks, or spammy practices? Take action: - For AI content: Audit, improve, or remove low-quality pages. - For backlinks: Build new, high-quality links from reputable sites. - For spam: Stop the practice and request reconsideration. Remember: Don't panic if you haven't been affected. Focus on creating people-first content that provides genuine value. Let me know your thoughts and experiences with the update! â€¦see more

â€œWhatâ€™s the lead source on that?â€ This is the endless game. Automation, attribution, data, multi-touch, influenceâ€¦ But Iâ€™ve always found conversion source to be a much more interesting data point. If we acknowledge that there are dozens of touch points across paid media, earn media, owned media, sales outreach, and old-fashioned marketing, then the importance of original lead source degrades over time. Alternatively, if we build a system around what made that person convert to a meeting or sign up, then that story can be more inclusive of everything in marketing and sales, in terms of actual, meaningful and insightful attribution. Plus, when you have so many leads coming from ZoomInfo and those types of list building tools, does lead source truly suggest anything meaningful here? Or would you rather know if it was a sales email, trade show activation, or paid ad that brought them into your conversion funnel? Going even further, this approach allows you to build a hybrid attribution model between self-sourced attribution and conversion source. Since we did this, itâ€™s helped us ask better questions, create content and calendaring, and know what motions are hitting and which arenâ€™t. â€¦see more

Yet, these interactions are not just roadblocks; they are stepping stones. Every objection, critique, and 'difficult' conversation is an untapped goldmine for honing your selling skills. Why? Comfort zones don't breed excellence. Challenged clients push us to analyze our approach, refine our pitch, and sharpen our problem-solving skills. They force us to listen more attentively, empathize more deeply, and negotiate more strategically. Imagine transforming every 'no' into a compelling reason to improve. Iâ€™ll be honest, you would be pivoting multiple times before you find a market-fit. Hereâ€™s why - because you donâ€™t know the problem. Personalized emails can increase open rates by up to 50% â€“ here's how to make it work for your brand ğŸ‘‡ 1) Segment your subscribers: Differentiate your email list based on customer behavior, such as purchase history, browsing habits, and engagement with previous emails. â†’ Segment customers who have purchased within the last 30 days from those who haven't purchased in over six months. Tailor your messaging to re-engage the latter with special offers or reminders about the benefits of your products. 2) Personalize subject lines: Create subject lines that include the recipient's name or reference past purchases. Studies show that personalized subject lines can increase open rates by 26%. â†’ Instead of a generic "Check out our new arrivals," try "John, new arrivals just for you!" or "Loved those shoes? Here are matching accessories!" 3) Tailored content: Use dynamic content blocks to personalize email content for different segments. For example, recommend products based on past purchases or show relevant content based on browsing behavior. â†’ For a customer who frequently purchases sportswear, include recommendations for new sports equipment or apparel. If a shopper has been browsing a particular category, such as electronics, highlight related products or special offers in that category. 4) A/B testing: Continuously A/B test your email campaigns to find the most effective personalization strategies. Test different variables such as subject lines, content layout, and send times. â†’ Test two versions of an email - one with a personalized subject line and one without. Compare open rates and use the winning subject line strategy in future campaigns. Similarly, test different call-to-action (CTA) placements to see which drives more clicks. 5) Analyze and adjust: Analyze the performance of personalized emails and adjust your strategy based on what you learn. â†’ Monitor metrics such as open rates, click-through rates, and conversion rates for your personalized emails. If a particular type of personalized content consistently performs well, include more of it in future campaigns. Conversely, if a strategy is underperforming, adjust your approach based on the data. ğŸ¤” How have you used personalization in your email campaigns, and what results have you seen? â€¦see more

In today's business world, where competition is fierce and clients are becoming increasingly demanding, an effective lead-generation strategy is critical to the success of any company. A proper understanding of the needs and pain points of your target audience is the key to creating compelling marketing messages that can capture the attention of potential clients and turn them into real leads. Sarah recently asked me this question, and here's what I had to say. Sarah: "Hey Dmitry, I've been reading up on effective lead gen strategies and something jumped out at me - the importance of really understanding our target market's pain points. This article says the hardest but most crucial step is pinpointing the specific needs our products solve." Me: "You're right, that is key. If we don't have a clear grasp of the problems we can solve for potential clients, our marketing messages are going to miss the mark." Sarah: "Exactly. It recommends looking at client feedback, support tickets, and even industry forums to identify common challenges. Then we can position what we offer as the solution." Me: "Smart approach. We should analyze our most successful projects over the past few years - what types of clients did we serve best? What were their key needs we addressed well?" Sarah: "Good call. If we can find patterns in the industries, company sizes, roles of the decision-makers, and business needs for our top projects, that gives us a template for an ideal client profile to target." Me: "Precisely. Then we verify that the profile is scalable by looking at how many similar prospective companies and contacts we could potentially reach out to on LinkedIn, email campaigns, etc. If it's in the thousands, we're in business!" Sarah: "Love this data-driven way to laser-focus our lead gen efforts. I'll start pulling reports on our biggest wins to analyze. This should sharpen our targeting." This dialogue emphasizes the importance of thoroughly analyzing the needs of your target audience and developing a data-driven lead-generation strategy. By scrutinizing successful past projects, identifying patterns, and testing the scalability of the target profile, a company can effectively target its marketing efforts and maximize its impact on potential clients. Using such a systematic and data-driven approach allows companies to spend lead generation resources wisely, increasing the chances of success in attracting new clients and growing their business. â€¦see more
The number 1 reason most cold emailers fail: They focus on learning, not executing. â†’ Reading every book on cold emailing. â†’ Spending weeks crafting the â€œperfectâ€ email template. â†’ Obsessing over the latest trends before sending a single email. The result? No progress. Here's what you should do instead: 1. Focus on one goal â†³ Get your first response. 2. A/B test everything: â†³ Subject lines, CTAs, offers. â†³ Learn by doing. 3. Send emails consistently: â†³ Volume over perfection. 4. Iterate quickly: â†³ Adjust based on what works â†³ And what doesnâ€™t. 5. Analyze results â†³ Use data to refine your approach. Stop trying to learn before you act. Start executing while you learn. Consistent, daily action is how you discover what really works. PS: I'm testing new subject lines today. What about you? â€¦see more

Here is a quick rundown of my recent sales memo. Thought to share with fellow sales leaders and ask if anything I missed. Please add your 2 to 20 cents in comments Let's face it, traditional sales calls can feel like a one-sided monologue. You rattle off features, benefits, and prices, hoping something sticks. The key lies in a holistic approach. Your sales call should be a dynamic exchange that explores your prospect's unique needs and challenges. Here's how to make it happen: Focus on Them, Not You: It's not about your product; it's about how it solves their problems. Ask insightful questions to uncover their pain points and goals. Become a Trusted Advisor: Show genuine interest in their business and offer helpful insights, even if it doesn't directly lead to a sale. This establishes you as a valuable resource. Embrace the Two-Way Street: Listen actively and respond thoughtfully to their concerns. The conversation should flow naturally, with both parties contributing. Creating Value Before the Close. Offer Free Consultations: Use the call to conduct a mini-audit of their current situation and provide actionable recommendations. Share Relevant Resources: Send them articles, case studies, or white papers that address their specific challenges. Connect Them with Others: If their needs fall outside your expertise, introduce them to someone who can help. People buy from those they trust and see as valuable partners. By fostering genuine connections and creating value upfront, you'll be well on your way to closing more deals and building lasting relationships. â€¦see more

POWERFUL B2B MARKETING TECHNIQUE: "If you can articulate your prospect's problems better than they can themselves, they will naturally assume you have the solution". When our copywriters are crafting persuasive text for websites, ads and videos we use a set of proprietary techniques we call 'Code V'. One of the most powerful of these techniques is: ğŸ’ğŸ’ğŸ’ Captivating attention right from the start of the piece by clearly articulating the target market's pain points. When you do this effectively, your audience FEELS that you understand them better than any of your competitors. They will FEEL an emotional connection with your brand. They'll be ready to hear more. Naturally, they assume you have the right solutions ... To do this well though, you need to TRULY understand the problems you solve for your clients at a very deep and precise level: ğŸ”¹How do THEY speak about their pain points? From their perspective, what is the cause of their pain? ğŸ”¹What are the exact words running through their psychology? ğŸ”¹What underlying emotion is driving them to solve it? ğŸ”¹What is their level of awareness of their problem? ğŸ”¹What solutions have they already tried and struggled with? KEY INSIGHT - you need to go deep and be specific. Most companies make the mistake of articulating surface-level problems only - so their marketing sounds exactly like all of their competitors. When executed correctly, the impact is powerful. However, it's NOT a manipulative technique. Because when you are one of the very few that have cared enough to really spend the effort on understanding your customers at that level of specificity... You will naturally be the provider to bring them the most value. . . . . â€¦see more

3 Surprising Things I learnt from SuperAI last week (By hanging out in the media room with fellow Tech reporters) 1. Content creation today = LOW probability of converting to sales. I've spoken to more than 3 top content creators in SuperAI- "top" defined as combined audience >1million across socials. They are facing content creation lethargy as fans want to be entertained with faster, quicker, more original content. This corroborates with the recent trend of youtubers mass-quitting. IF the focus is on monetization of expertise, a strategy that is based 100% on content creation is NOT the way to go. Creators, business founders and freelancers need some sort of strategy on using AI to streamline the outbound sales process too. Niche =/= revenue. Sales = revenue. So important to distinguish! 2. We'll see in the next 1-3 years, the rise of companies with small teams (<10pax) doing 7/8 figure annual revenue. And they will do so via multiple "Agentic AIs". Agentic AI is an AI system designed to achieve complex goals and manage workflows with minimal human supervision. It has advanced capabilities to understand context, make decisions, adapt to changing circumstances, and autonomously complete multifaceted tasks. So a team will use AAIs to basically to assign each AAI with a defined "stakeholder" role, and then asking them to work with each other. Sounds good to me btw, as the AAI system seems to be able to eliminate unnecessary human drama and politics. 3. Because of the above points 1-2, it is necessary to have a stand on "AI". We all know that AI can be a tool or a trap. The mass media also LOVES to fear monger- with stuff like "AI's gonna replace you baby!" The point is, most people WANT AIs to be their allies. Scoring your #b2b leads wonâ€™t work. If not done right. After seeing many scoring systems I have to say I became a bit more sceptical if it really works. âŒWhy would accumulating opens, clicks and visits equal buying intent? âŒWhy wouldnâ€™t your prospect just reach out, if there was buying intent? âŒWhy would SDRs call someone just because they downloaded some template? âŒ If your content is shit, scoring wonâ€™t save you! However, if done right it can work and give your sales team additional pipeline. After all itâ€™s better than cold outreach in terms of Conversion Rates. âœ…Score Ideal Customer Fit (company size, industry, revenue) âœ…If you score engagement, keep it separate from ICP score. âœ…Donâ€™t include email opens in you engagement score. âœ… Be aware of scoring clicks! âœ…Donâ€™t score sources - yes, search is usually higher buying intent, but it also depends on the keyword. âœ…Donâ€™t forget you are dealing with people. Check your scoring! âœ… Rather take something out of the box than create your own. âœ…Check quality with you sales team and revise. Finally keep it simple! If you have low lead volume, itâ€™s not worth the hassle to come up with a complicated scoring model. P.S. How are you scoring your leads? â€¦see more

Fri, Jul 12, 10:00 PM Path to Product Management Event by Clarusway New Generation Education - AWS & DevOps, Data Science, Full-Stack Dev., Product Management Online 6,397 attendees View event Fri, Aug 16, 10:00 AM Evaluation and continuous monitoring of competence of laboratory personnel Event by MiChem Dynamics (Pty) Ltd Online 76 attendees View event
Top of Mind Awareness: A Crucial Marketing Principle in a Contracting Economy In a contracting economy, Top of Mind Awareness (TOMA) becomes a critical marketing principle. As consumer spending tightens, it is essential for your business to be the first one that comes to your target audience's mind. Achieving this requires leveraging a strong Unique Selling Proposition (USP) through effective marketing strategies. Illustrating the Concept: Imagine my girlfriend and I deciding where to go for dinner and drinks in town. With 20 options available, none truly stand out, leading us to spend 15 minutes deciding. Given the rising food prices, this is now a weekly outing at most. Sometimes, we may choose to eat at home first and then go out for a couple of beers to fulfill our social needs. Many local businesses struggle because they lack a compelling USP or the robust marketing needed to remain top-of-mind for consumers. The Importance of Strong Top Line Revenue and Creativity: Strong top-line revenue, combined with creativity, can address most business challenges. However, as the top line contracts, businesses have fewer opportunities to pivot or adapt. When consumer spending decreases, businesses relying on staff compensated through tips face additional challenges. Tight revenue limits the ability to subsidize tips with hourly pay increases, leading to staff dissatisfaction, increased workload, and ultimately a decline in service quality and retention. Strategic Recommendations: Understanding and implementing TOMA and a robust USP may not completely prevent these challenges, but they position your business for better survival and growth as the economic cycle recovers. Local businesses should identify at least one highly marketable key component and promote it relentlessly. Aim to establish your business as a destination and continuously engage both new and existing audiences to drive top-line revenue. By focusing on these principles, your business can navigate the challenges of a contracting economy and emerge stronger as conditions improve. â€¦see more
5 Ways E-commerce Entrepreneurs Should Be Using Data to Grow Their Business: If youâ€™re a young ecom brand looking to take the leap to the next level, you need to be leveraging your data. Guessing what your customers want and need is never the right approach. Here are five powerful (and easy-ish) strategies to start making more data-driven decisions today. 1. Optimize Conversion Rates with Heat Maps Utilize heat map tools like Hotjar to gain insights into user behavior on your site. By visualizing where visitors click, scroll, and drop off, you can identify friction points and optimize your siteâ€™s layout, calls-to-action, and navigation. This leads to a smoother user experience and higher conversion rates. 2. Improve Merchandising through Customer Surveys Imagine you knew exactly what your customers wanted to buy from youâ€¦well you can. Conduct regular customer surveys to gather valuable feedback on product preferences and shopping experiences. Analyzing this data helps you understand customer needs and tailor your product offerings accordingly. 3. Use Organic Social Data to inform what Content you Share Across other Channels Use social media analytics tools to track engagement, reach, and conversion metrics from your organic social media efforts. Understanding what content resonates with your audience allows you to refine your strategy across all of your marketing channels, and double down on creating more similar content. 4. Inform Copywriting and Product Development with Customer Reviews Collect and analyze customer reviews using tools like Yotpo or Okendo. Look for common themes and feedback to improve your product descriptions and highlight key features. Additionally, use this feedback to guide product improvements or new product development, enhancing customer satisfaction and driving repeat purchases. 5. Optimize Pricing Strategies through Competitive Analysis Conduct competitive pricing analysis to understand how your prices compare to those of similar products in the market. Use this data to adjust your pricing strategy dynamically, ensuring competitiveness without sacrificing profit margins. An app like Intelligems can help you implement competitive pricing strategies efficiently. Competitive pricing can attract price-sensitive customers and boost sales. By integrating these data-driven strategies into your e-commerce operations, you can make informed decisions that directly contribute to revenue growth. Data is your most valuable asset in scaling your Shopify business and achieving sustainable success. â€¦see more

For instance, "Can you share what your top priorities are this quarter?" 3ï¸âƒ£ Use your research to ask insightful questions: "I saw your company recently expanded. One simple question you should know about your sales reps. Yesterday, during a conversation with a manager, I could tell they were frustrated with a rep. The rep is performing to the standard, but the manager is frustrated because they feel it could be better. Knowing the situation, I asked, "Do you know if they even have to work?" "That's a good question, I don't know." "Do you know why they work there?" "I have never asked the question." I see so many top individual contributors who were promoted to manager struggle with this situation, myself included, early on. Reps that have the potential to be an A player but just won't put in the extra work as you did as a rep. Figuring out why they are there and what drives them is what always helped me the most. My favorite reason I ever heard was: "I just want to be able to afford traveling and going on Yachts in the summer." There will be different reasons for different people. The more you know the better chance you have of developing A Players. Will it work every time? NO! The biggest thing that helped me was understanding that not everyone was going to be an A player and being okay with that. â€¦see more
Your salary & bonus is dependent on your manager's feedback. HOWEVER, there is something even more important IF you are in your services industry! . . . Client feedback! And there are multiple ways to control the client feedback. YES. You can influence the feedback from the client in a very friendly/positive way. method #1: Writing a status email EVERY week. CC ing your manager and client manger. and don't forget to write this sentence at the end. "PLEASE LET ME KNOW IF YOU HAVE ANY CONCERNS". You are pushing your client share a concern then and there. So that nothing adds up by the end of year/appraisal cycle. method #2: Asking your client for feedback on the calls once every month AND asking "What worked last month". Push your client to think about a positive incident & it will stick in their head. ***** This might or might not work - But this is good practice & this behaviour will help you eventually. P2P Q& A: 1. What is the P2P process? Ans: The P2P process encompasses all the steps from identifying the need for goods or services, through procurement, receiving, invoicing, and finally paying the supplier. 2. What is a purchase requisition? Ans: A purchase requisition is an internal request created by a department or individual within a company to initiate the purchasing of goods or services. 3. What is a purchase order (PO)? Ans: A purchase order is a formal document issued by a buyer to a supplier, outlining the types, quantities, and agreed prices for products or services. 4. What are the key components of a purchase order? Ans: Key components include order number, supplier information, delivery address, billing address, items requested, quantities, prices, terms and conditions, and payment terms. 5. How do you handle supplier selection and evaluation? Ans: Supplier selection and evaluation involve researching potential suppliers, assessing their qualifications, requesting quotes, and evaluating based on criteria such as quality, price, delivery, and reliability. 6. What is a three-way match? Ans: The three-way match is a process that compares a supplierâ€™s invoice with the purchase order and receiving report to ensure accuracy and consistency before authorizing payment. 7. How do you handle discrepancies in invoices? Ans: Discrepancies can be handled by communicating with the supplier to resolve any differences, adjusting the invoice, and documenting the resolution process. 8. What is an accounts payable aging report? Ans: An accounts payable aging report shows the outstanding invoices grouped by periods (e.g., 30, 60, 90 days past due) and is used to manage cash flow and payment schedules. 9. What role does technology play in the P2P process? Ans: Technology streamlines the P2P process with automated requisitioning, approval workflows, electronic data interchange (EDI), and invoice processing systems. 10. What is vendor management? Ans: Vendor management involves overseeing the relationship between the company and its suppliers, including performance monitoring, contract negotiation, and maintaining healthy relationships. 11. How do you handle urgent or rush orders? Ans: Urgent or rush orders require prioritization, expediting the procurement process, and effective communication with suppliers to ensure timely delivery. 12. What is a blanket purchase order? Ans: A blanket purchase order is an agreement between a buyer and a supplier to purchase a specific amount of goods or services over a while at an agreed-upon price. 13. How do you manage inventory levels? Ans: Managing inventory involves monitoring stock levels, forecasting demand, and placing orders promptly to avoid shortages or overstocking. â€¦see more

I've said it before and I'll say it again and again, there's power in repetition. I recently delved into the concept of the "Repetition Effect" in my article and I couldn't help but notice something fascinating. I observed that we often underestimate the value of repeating a message or action until it becomes second nature. What I noticed was that when we repeat an action or message, it not only ingrains the habit but also amplifies its impact. Think about it: how many times have you had to hear "Yeah All Good" before it became a reflexive part of your vocabulary? Which made me think about the power of repetition in digital marketing and business management. Repeating your brand's core message consistently across various platforms doesn't just inform your audienceâ€”it solidifies your brand's presence in their minds. And that's when I realised that businesses that embrace the repetition effect are the ones that truly thrive. They don't shy away from repeating their message, their vision, or their values. Instead, they harness the power of repetition to create a strong, cohesive brand identity. So, here's my advice: Don't be afraid to repeat yourself whether it's reminding your team of your company's mission or reiterating your brand messageâ€”embrace the power of repetition. Want to learn more about the Repetition Effect and how it can benefit your business? Read more PS: If you enjoyed this post or found it useful, connect and follow me here on LinkedIn. Remember to turn on the notification bell to stay updated with the latest insights in digital marketing and personal development. â€¦voir plus Voir la traduction

The transformation of Paris into a cyclist-friendly city is a testament to the power of sustainable urban planning, according to circular economist Harald Friedl. Only 4% of journeys in the French capital are made in a private car, Friedl says, noting there are several reasons why cycling has surged. "Paris has invested heavily in cycling infrastructure, creating over 1,000km of bike-friendly paths, including 300km of dedicated bike lanes," he says. "This extensive network has made cycling a safe and convenient option for daily commutes." The city's mayor has also introduced "numerous policies to reduce car usage," he says, including tripling parking charges for SUVs and closing major roads to motorists. Other reasons include the removal of city centre car-parking spaces and a "clear vision to make Paris a 100% cycling city". How do you think we should move around cities? Share your thoughts in the comments below. â€¦see more

ğŸš¨ Fredrik Cassel is a general partner at Creandum, which has just raised a new â‚¬500m (Â£422m) startup fund. He talks to Sam Shead for VC Wednesdays, a weekly series featuring a Q&A interview with a venture capitalist. ğŸ–Šï¸ What advantage do VCs with a scientific background have over those with a finance background? Formal education is a very small part of what creates advantage as an investor. For me, curiosity is the most important trait in a VC, and that can be found in many walks of life. When you add experience from operations and from working closely with founders across many successes and failures, you will have a recipe that compounds over time. That is if you manage to keep an open and humble approach. This is going to be a generalisation but I would say that those with an engineering background are more interested in how things are connected in the world, excluding money. And those with a finance background are more focused on how they are connected because of money. Both are important as an investor. For the most part, I have an easier time connecting closely and quickly with entrepreneurs focused on product or use-case first. ğŸ–Šï¸ How can VCs have impact when theyâ€™re on a startup board? Our job as investors is to help founders hire the best people, connect them to the most meaningful partners and focus on the things that will really drive value. This support can take many forms. Oftentimes, not least initially, it can be very tactical â€“ late-night calls on simple matters like tactics to win a customer over or pricing structures. At other times itâ€™s more pivotal, such as helping to secure a big hire, or setting the company up for â€“ and ultimately successfully â€“ closing large further financing. The best investors provide a mix of support across all levels and are there for founders when they really need it, but also know when to stay out. As companies mature, the board becomes a more important forum for the strategic topics mentioned. It is typically not loved by founders until they either find a way to make it work for them by honing their board management skills, or the value grows on them. This can be the case, for instance, where youâ€™ve built your venture over many funding rounds and have an increasingly large and complex investor base. The boardâ€™s role as a designated subset of investors can be hugely valuable, giving founders time back and leverage. ğŸ–Šï¸ How much of an issue is the lack of growth-stage funding in Europe? Our experience is that the best companies have access to growth capital regardless of the point in the macro cycle and regardless of geography. If anything, thereâ€™s almost 10 times more growth funding available today in Europe than 10 years ago. I am convinced that the current and next cohort of growth-stage European companies will be more able than any time before to compete for the biggest and most ambitious growth investors on the planet. â€¦more

Pour rappel, le LBO est la reine des techniques financiÃ¨res, parce quâ€™elle permet de gagner (beaucoup) dâ€™argent, sans mÃªme avoir Ã  amÃ©liorer les performances de la sociÃ©tÃ© rachetÃ©e. Sur le financement du rachat - La valorisation de lâ€™entreprise : EBITDA x Multiple EBITDA - La dette : EBITDA x Multiple de Dette - Lâ€™equity que vous devez mettre : Valorisation - Dette Puis, vous allez descendre le rÃ©sultat : - EBIT : EBITDA â€“ DÃ©prÃ©ciation et amortissements, - EBT : EBIT â€“ IntÃ©rÃªt de la dette - RÃ©sultat : EBT â€“ 25% de taxe Il faut savoir combien de combien de cash vous disposez pour payer la dette : - Les Free Cash Flow : RÃ©sultat + dÃ©prÃ©ciation et amortissement - Capex Il ne restera plus quâ€™Ã  faire des calculs de sortie - Valorisation dâ€™entreprise : EBITDA actualisÃ©e par la croissance annuelle - Dette nette : Dette initiale â€“ Free Cash Flow (tous les cash flows servent Ã  rembourser la dette) - Valorisation de sortie : Valorisation dâ€™entreprise â€“ Dette Nette. Enfin, les retours sur investissement - Le multiple : La Valorisation de sortie / Equity initial - Le TRI : le Multiple ^ (1/nombre dâ€™annÃ©e) â€“ 1 Si vous ne voulez pas vous trompez, jâ€™ai fait un petit excel. As someone who used to be in sales, I think itâ€™s incredibly important to do your research on people and be mindful of treating those you are reaching out to likeâ€¦HUMANS with real lives, circumstances, and tragedies beyond what you can comprehend. I had an SDR reach out to me five times about an L&D service even after my recent post about my husband passing away after his long battle with cancer. Iâ€™m just trying to stay alive and make it through the day, and no I do not have time to get on a call for this service I frankly do not care about. Iâ€™m not knocking anyone for doing their job, but please - take the extra 5 minutes and do your due diligence to create a personalized message. If this person had reached out to me with condolences and asked if they could send me a gift card to help with food, that might have been a totally different situation. Tech bubbles are part of a cycle, according to Steve O'Hear, a former journalist who now runs a communications agency. "Weâ€™ve had them before, and weâ€™ll have them again," he writes. "The truth is, the technology, ideas and human capital invested in fields that don't fully pan out often end up benefiting society in unexpected ways. Even if many of those companies don't survive, their innovations leave a lasting impact that is not always obvious at the time." He adds: "Although many [artificial intelligence] startups might not succeed in the long term and will fail during the current cycle of heightened interest and investment in AI, the advancements in technology, as well as the skills and knowledge developed by the people working in these startups, will continue to have a positive impact for many years to come." Do you think we are currently in a tech bubble which will burst any time soon? Share your thoughts in the comments below. â€¦more
ğŸš¨ From Founders Forum Group and Founders Factory, to firstminute capital, Tech Nation and London Tech Week (LTW), Brent Hoberman is a tech investor juggling plenty of plates. He joins Sam Shead for VC Wednesdays, a weekly series featuring a Q&A interview with a venture capitalist. ğŸ–Šï¸Why are events like LTW and Founders Forum so important, and how have they evolved? LTW has become a landmark moment for the UK tech sector, with the community coming together to take stock, collaborate and shine a light on progress being made. Weâ€™ve doubled in size this year, with more than 30,000 attendees convening at Olympia this week. Itâ€™s a great opportunity for inward investment, marked by the presence of numerous country delegations and large corporates exploring collaborations with early stage startups. The week has evolved into a comprehensive platform with rising stars competitions, workshops, spin-off and side events. My first ever job interview: Interviewer: So I have to ask you the big question. Me: Okay! Interviewer: Would you call yourself a believer? I had applied to a Production Company. There was zero mention that it was for Crossing Over with John Edward, the psychic medium who talks to dead people. Me: Ummmâ€¦a believer? Yes. Sure I would. Interviewer: Really? You can be honest. Me: Oh sure. Sure. Why not believe? Interviewer: Iâ€™m skeptical myself. But it really doesnâ€™t matter one way or the other right? Me: No. It doesnâ€™t. Interviewer: Haha exactly. Our job isnâ€™t wrangling ghosts. Me: Haha totally not. I literally didnâ€™t know what I was talking about. Interviewer: So you seem like a good fit. What do you say? Me: I *believe* Iâ€™ll take the job. Interviewer: Hahaha. Great! Again I had no idea what was going on. And I learned a good lesson for the subsequent billion interviews that I did not get hired on: Itâ€™s not always about you, how you prepare and how confident you pretend to be, your research, your cliche questions and interrogative acumen. Itâ€™s often about them, their preconceptions, misconceptions, their mood. And a whole host of things you have no control over. Sometimes itâ€™s best not to change. And believe! (in yourself). â€¦more

No salary in the job listing? It's a game. Let's outplay them... Employers will skip advertising the salary when: 1. They donâ€™t know what the going rate is 2. They donâ€™t want to alert existing employees at the same level of what theyâ€™re willing to pay 3. They want room to negotiate 4. They donâ€™t want to alert competition It doesnâ€™t help you when you apply. Here is what you can do, ask politely: â€œI was wondering if you could provide some insight into the salary range for this position. I want to make sure we're potentially aligned from the beginning." Now, if they... > say it's too early to discuss salary: "I completely understand. I'm just looking for a ballpark figure to ensure we're in the same range. Could you perhaps share a general range?" > ask what your current salary is: "I'd prefer to focus on the value I can bring to this role and whether that aligns with your budget. Could you share the range you have in mind?" > f they say they don't have a range: "I appreciate your transparency. Could you perhaps share what a person with similar responsibilities might expect in terms of compensation?" If youâ€™re a good fit for the job and they have good values, then donâ€™t be afraid to ask. Have you ever been in this situation? Share what you did in order to help others. â€¦more

He showed up to his 9am interview hung over. I appreciated his honesty. He said "I was out drinking and didn't get home until 5 in the morning. Can we reschedule? I'm hung over, tired and not feeling well". Against better judgement, I acquiesced. I remembered seeing a post here on LinkedIn of someone holding a sign saying "behind every job seeker is a person with hopes, dreams and a family". That resonated and so I rescheduled for the next day. After the interview, I hired him on the spot and he became one of the best performers on the team! It's incredible how thing always work out this way! Nah, that didn't happen. Not a chance. That kind of unbelievable drivel comes from the influencers. What really happened? We reminded him that he was interviewing for a safety sensitive position that required a CDL, drug & alcohol testing and working with and around heavy equipment and that being under the influence of alcohol was a violation of the state and federal regulations of such roles. We said that he could not safely do the job under the influence and that the safety of everyone on the site would be compromised by someone showing up intoxicated. That was completely unacceptable. If he could not show up to an interview sober, why would we think he could show up to work sober? We noted the interview would not be rescheduled and that he was no longer being considered for the role. Then had him call a friend to get a safe ride home. We see a lot of fluff on here. A lot. It's intended to go viral, not to actually be helpful. Not every hire turns out to be superb. Not every person gets a second chance. That's fluff. Sometimes skill beats attitude. Sometimes, experience wins. Sometimes, NOT making the hire.....is the best decision. And sometimes, something strange like this happens. And it doesn't have the fairy tale ending that we've come accustomed to seeing here. That's reality. The best advice for a successful job search that I can think of is to be focused, structured, have a plan and put your best foot forward, always. And if you follow advice from people here, its best to do so from people who have experience in what they are talking about. Even then, use critical thinking. Good luck! â€¦more

Refining ResNet-18 Model Performance: A Deep Learning Analysis Model Overview: Trained a ResNet-18 model with frozen weights to evaluate its performance over 20 epochs. : 1. Training Accuracy: Improved steadily from 59.1% to 75.2%. 2. Test Accuracy: Reached a peak of 75.2%, showing consistent generalization across unseen data. 3. Loss Patterns: The training and test losses showed a consistent decline and then stabilized, indicating controlled learning with less overfitting. -Tuned Model: 1. The fine-tuned model achieved higher training accuracy (97.3%) but had more fluctuation in test loss and accuracy. 2. The frozen model showed more stable test accuracy (around 75%) but did not reach the same peak performance. : 1. Hybrid Strategy: Freeze initial layers and fine-tune later layers to leverage pre-trained features while learning task-specific representations. 2. Regularization: Introduce dropout, L2 regularization, or batch normalization to minimize overfitting. 3. Learning Rate Scheduler: Implement dynamic learning rate adjustments to fine-tune training. 4. Cross-Validation: Utilize cross-validation for more robust performance evaluation. 5. Data Augmentation: Apply data augmentation techniques to enhance model generalization. : I plan to experiment with these strategies to find the optimal balance between training accuracy and generalization. Excited to share more updates soon! Data source: , ,,,,,,,,,, â€¦more

We began with the future, we delved into purpose-driven growth, we embraced in rethinking innovation, we organized for sustainable innovation to finally put it in practice through real cases. The essence of sustainable innovation lies in its ability to align with both business and societal needs. The concept of Future Solving, as introduced in our series, suggests a paradigm shiftâ€”one where we envision the desired future and work backward to identify the steps needed to achieve it. This approach is vital in an era where financial and social interests are increasingly aligned, making sustainability not just a moral imperative but a strategic advantage. Navigating the complexities of todayâ€™s worldâ€”what has been termed a â€œpoly-crisisâ€ environmentâ€”requires innovative management that prioritizes human-centric approaches and values creativity as a core asset. As we face the critical environmental and societal impacts of emerging technologies like the AI, it becomes evident that sustainability must be embedded at the core of innovation. The rapid advancements in these fields pose significant risks to our planet and people if not managed with a sustainability-first mindset. The challenge is not in the technologies themselves but in how we choose to utilize them to create a positive impact rather than exacerbate existing issues. It can be used in various fields such as construction, interior design, and home renovations. âœ…ğ‡ğ¨ğ° ğ¢ğ­ ğ–ğ¨ğ«ğ¤ğ¬ The device emits a laser beam, and when the beam hits a surface, it calculates the distance based on the time it takes for the light to return. Working in 40Â°c temperature & carrying vegetables on their heads at streets bare foot in the hot sun to earn 300rs a day This is the state of these marginal farmers today. We're working Small and marginal farmers, who often cultivate less than one hectare, face significant challenges in selling their produce. Growing just 30 kg of vegetables or 30 bunches of greens daily, their harvest is too small for agents to purchase. Imagine the heartbreak of these hardworking farmers, carrying their produce on their heads for miles, only to sell it for very little money on the streets. This labor-intensive effort, under the scorching sun, yields minimal income. At, we are committed to connecting these farmers like these with SMEs like hotels, cafes, retails and all the SMEs ensuring their hard work translates into fair returns. *Know your audience* It all starts with understanding who you're talking to. Tailor your content to their interests, challenges, and online behavior. What kind of content resonates with them? What questions do they have? By building a buyer persona, you can ensure your posts are relevant and provide value. *Craft Compelling Headlines:* The first impression is everything. Your headline is prime real estate, so use it wisely. *Here are some tips:** Keep it short and sweet. People are busy scrolling, so grab their attention quickly. Use strong verbs and clear language. Ask a question to pique curiosity. Highlight a benefit or solution. * Tell a Story:* Facts and figures are important, but stories are what truly connect with people. Weave a narrative into your posts to evoke emotions and make your message memorable. Share customer success stories, industry insights, or behind-the-scenes glimpses of your company culture. *Spark Conversation:* Social media is a two-way street. Don't just broadcast messages â€“ encourage interaction. Ask questions, respond to comments, and participate in relevant conversations. This fosters a sense of community and keeps your audience coming back for more. â€¦more

I am extremely excited to announce that our work on modeling realistic 3D dense crowds of humans has been already published in TOG and will be presented at ACM SIGGRAPH Asia 2024 in Tokyo, Japan! In this paper we approximate each human body with a parametric set of 3D volumetric proxies, and we resolve human-human interactions with a physically based contact model while maintaining the overall motion of the crowd. We validate our approach through an extensive user study, using videos of crowds at 5 different density levels, rendered from 4 viewpoints for stationary and non-stationary cases. This is a joint work from(Madrid, Spain) and(Rennes, France), as part of the. I would also like to thank all the people that participated in the project, especiallyandfor their great guidance and mentorship andfor the hard work, keep up the cool ideas! For more details feel free to check our project website: Or the TOG publication: See you at the conference ğŸ˜„ â€¦more
